'Ancient Empires' has quickly become the standard by which all other rule systems for miniatures has been measured. Combining ease of play with careful attention to historical detail, the discerning gamer is able to accurately recreate the wars of antiquity.

CONTENTS

- Over forty pages of rules and scenarios, spanning from the earliest part of Caesar's rule to the end.

- Easy to use charts and tables listing over twenty different troop types, including historical leader ratings.

- Background and history of the wars and times.

Expands:

    Ancient Empires: A Simulation of the Wars of Antiquity

title: NWS: Nights of Fury – Guadalcanal Naval Battles
description:
NWS: Nights of Fury - Guadalcanal Naval Battles is the first in a series of high intensity naval combat naval wargames that will offer realism and detail yet have streamlined and hard hitting game play for 2 players or solitaire play. Full color cards with highly detailed ship graphics for easy and quick recognition. Full color and detailed marker cards, random event cards, battle map, and plastic damage markers are also included. Full color island cards showing Savo, Florida, and Guadalcanal islands will also be used for the battle map. Scenario cards will include random events, weather, visibility, land effects, and other cards that will determine the setup and play of the battle. Quick result combat modifier charts will also be included to allow for fast reference to determine combat results.

All the critical details will be covered such as flotation and structural damage, spotting and detection, Admiral capabilities, formations, maneuvers, land effects, radar effects, armor ratings, fire controls, torpedo combat, gunnery, evasion, combat range effects, random events, crew qualities, searchlights and starshells, and more. This is not your typical generic naval card game where realism and detail are sacrificed for the sake of playability. The USN, RAN, and IJN ships each have their own researched and calculated combat factors and with the details to make combat realistic and effective. A rapid fire, efficient, and easy to learn combat system with basic, advanced, solitaire, and optional rules. No other naval combat card game has yet to incorporate the features this combat system will handle.

Game Info is available at: http://forums.navalwarfare.org/showthread.php?t=32

title: Operation: Aliens
types: Horror Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
description:
From the game:

The Starship Narcissus answers a distress call from a nearby planet. On board is a task force of colonial marines. Now, four days later, only a handful remain, after a desperate battle between man and alien on the planet's surface.

These few marines believe themselves safe on board the Narcissus, as she hurtles through space, leaving the terrible planet a million miles behind her.

But that's when the nightmare really begins...

The object of the game is to survive long enough to set the ship on self destruct by visiting the three coded control panels. Weaponry and the sick bay help the Marines achieve their goal. Once all the self destruct areas have been activated, the Marine must begin the countdown by activating the ship's computer in the computer room. Then the Marines must leave the 'Narcissus' before the ship explodes, via the escape capsule on the bridge...but beware the Queen Alien! Remember, in space no one can hear you scream!

This game was for the officially licensed Operation: Aliens cartoon series based on the Aliens movie.

title: VBAM Source: Empire Rising
types: Civilization Exploration Negotiation Science Fiction Territory Building Wargame
description:
Thirty years before the outbreak of the Escalation Wars, the Circasian Empire was a small, largely insignificant power located on the edge of known space. However, the Circasians were not weak. Decades of brutal anti-raider warfare forced the Circasian Star Forces to learn and adapt to the hostile universe which surrounded them.

The lessons learned in the Raider Wars would be put to the test when, after years of thinly veiled hostility over the negotiating table, the actions of the Chouka Theocracy finally forced the Circasian Empire to make a fateful decision. By order of the War Council, a fleet was dispatched to begin a pre-emptive invasion of Chouka space. The Chouka War had begun.

The Escalation Wars: Empire Rising details both the history of the Chouka War and the powers involved in the conflict. All of the materials and special rules needed to play out the war are provided within the pages of this supplement. Unit lists are provided for the Circasian Empire, Chouka Theocracy, Sshelath Alliance, various raiders, and civilians.

title: Travel  with Woody Woodpecker
description: Spin and move childrens game which has the unusual feature of having the board have a circular rotating area which causes the track of the game to change during the game. The object is to fly around the world landing in 5 different countries to win.

title: A Fist Full of Throttle
description: Warning: A Fist Full of Throttle is the Ultimate, 100% knock down drag em' out Rock  Roll, boogie woogie till' ya puke, adult, biker lifestyle board game. Play A Fist Full Of Throttle........ And remember Keep The Shiny Side Up And Rock On!!!!

title: Windsurfin game
description: This is a Japanese Windsurfing Game from Ad Technos as part of their sports and leisure section.

title: Where's Waldo? Waldo Watcher Card Game
description: Card game for Ages 5 and up based on the popular children's books. Players watch for Waldo as cards are played face up into the center of the table. Waldo Watchers hurry to be the first to slap down their I Found Waldo cards when they spot him. The winner crosses off one of the letters of WALDO on the score pad. Cross them all off and you win the game.

title: Goren's Cutthroat Bridge for Three
description:
In the 1960s, Milton Bradley capitalized upon the popularity of bridge by publishing a series of games by bridge master Charles H. Goren. This is one of the more obscure titles in this series.

The game is described as, An exciting, fast playing bridge game that scores differently and simply for 3, 4, or 5 players with one winner. It is strictly cutthroat in the bidding, but it creates a variety of partnerships against declarers after the bidding. The new and novel scoring system forces players to bid daringly, and sometimes play with exuberance.

The game includes a plastic playing platform with pegs to track bids, scoring, and card slots to facilitate dummy play.

title: U.S.A. Bicentennial Game
description:
An enjoyable game for Americans of all ages.

Players roll and move around a board decorated with photographs of American icons (e.g., the Statue of Liberty). Each space has a number. Land on the space, select a category card, and attempt to answer the corresponding trivia question. The difficulty of the questions varies widely. The more difficult the question, the more stars it is worth. The first player to earn 50 stars wins the game.

title: The Game is Nirtz
description:
This abstract game consists of a plastic game board (9x9 matrix), ten red and ten yellow tokens (numbered 1-5; two tokens of each number), and a plastic storage tray.

At the onset of the game, players arrange their tokens in two straight rows at opposite ends of the board. The objective of the game is to move the tokens to form a straight unbroken line of 7 tokens across the board, extending at a right angle to the original arrangement. Players take turns, each moving one token at a time. Tokens are moved the number of spaces indicated (i.e., token five must move five spaces).

The game includes two variations.

title: Turn The Terrible Tank
description:
From the box ...

An all-family game by Tomy.  Fire steel balls down the track to keep the tank from turning its terrible nose on you.  If you hit, the terrible tank turns on your opponent.  If you miss, it keeps coming and blasts your anti-tank gun into the air.  The exciting, two-player game of skill, strategy, and timing.

Setup:
1. Install 2 AA batteries in the Terrible Tank.
2. Remove the steel ball bearings from center bridge supports storage compartment.
3. Assemble the two piece plastic bridge with the center support and an anti-tank gun emplacement at each end.
4. Lock the gun emplacement's explosion spring loaded arms.
5. Place the molded fake guns over the arms.
6. Load each gun emplacement with 6 balls.
7. Place the Terrible Tank on the center of the bridge with the turret facing perpendicular to the bridge.
8. Unleash hell (eg: turn on the tank).

Play:
After powered on, the Terrible Tank will start heading down one side of the bridge or the other.  Instead of a main gun, the Terrible Tank features a spinning pointed auger ... hence the Terribleness of the aforementioned Tank.

The player being advanced upon must use the plunger on his gun emplacement to fire steel balls at a target switch under the Terrible Tank.  When hit, the target switch will cause the Terrible Tank's turret to turn 180 degrees and reverse the motor to advance upon the opponent.

The target moves in and out of the Terrible Tank so a successful shot must be timed to hit the target when it is exposed.  A robotic driver also moves in and out of the top of Terrible Tank's turret.  Since the driver and target are synchronized, a successful shot will reach the Terrible Tank as the driver and target are fully exposed.

If the Terrible Tank advances all the way to a gun emplacement, it triggers a spring loaded explosion and your opponent gains a point.

Two counters on the center bridge support show the progress of the game.  The first person to reach six points win.

title: La Bataille de l'Ebre, 1938
types: Civil War Wargame World War II
description:
La Bataille de l'Ebre, 1938 (The battle of the Ebro) is a simulation of the first decisive days of the largest and bloodiest clash of the Spanish Civil War: the Republican Ebro offensive and the subsequent Nationalist counteroffensive(July-November 1938).

The game is designed to simulate the combats that occurred from July 25th to August 4th 1938 on the Ebro at a Brigade scale.
The Ejercito Popular (Popular Republican Army) is represented by battalions or brigades, and the Ejercito Nacional (Nationalist Army) by battalions, regiments or half brigades (3-4 battalions).
Air units represents  groups of 2-3 squadrons (30-40 fighters or 50-70 bombardiers).
An hexagon represents 1.5km and a game turn one day.

A turn is divided between four phases:
A- Aerian phase
=Assignations (where players choose were their planes will go)
= Aerian combat (between fighters in the same zone)
= Bombardments

B- Republican phase
= Reinforcements
= Movements
= Terrestrian combat

C- Nationalist phase (same as Republican phase)
D- End of turn phase

The game includes:

     6 pages rules
     2 play aid sheets
     1 counter sheet 
     one A2 map.

title: Round the Rails Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme Novel-based Trains Transportation
description: A Thomas  Friends game played on a circular, plastic track/board with a Fat Controller spinner in the middle.  Contains a plastic Thomas the Tank Engine with two troublesome trucks, 4 color-coded lorry cards and 4 sets of 4 cargo cards.

title: Carrier War: the War in the Pacific 1941-1945 – 1944-1946 Expansion Kit
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
Carrier War is a strategic level simulation in Pacific. The 1944-1946 allows players to complete the war. New rules expand upon those of Carrier War: the War in the Pacific 1941-1945 covering events which occurred late in war. The expansion also includes the British Pacific Fleets.

Contents:

    1944-1946 Expansion booklet
    400 full color die cut playing pieces
    7 play aid cards




Expands:

    Carrier War: the War in the Pacific 1941-1945

title: My First Brain Quest Preschool Animal Matching
description: Memory game with sturdy animal tiles.  Little kids (1-2) like just looking at and playing with the tiles.  Bigger kids (2-4) learn the matching concept, and bigger still (4-5) can play it as Memory.  Comes in cubic box with nice production values.

title: KISS on Tour Game
description:
The contents of the box are as follows:
1 Game Board
10 City Cards
15 Kiss Cards
5 Record Cards
5 Fan Cards
2 Dice
4 Player Pieces

The board is laid out as a large star, and players move their pawns out from the record store space, as they follow the band on tour.

title: The Great Ontario Trivia Challenge
description:
This game is a roll-and-move trivia game, using questions based on the history and culture of the province of Ontario, Canada. The board depicts two concentric game tracks around the edges , and the center has a stylized map of the province. The questions are divided into five categories: Sports; History; Industry; People; Places.

Contents:
Gameboard 
Ontario Trivia Question Book 8 Game Pawns 
32 Loon Coins 
1 Die 
1 Bookmark
8 player tokens

title: Stalingrad
description:
This is a Japanese wargame on the battle for Stalingrad in World War II.

700 die cut counters.
4 20x60cm mounted map board.

1 Hex=25km
1 Game Turn=2Weeks
From the Beginning of Case Blue July to November 1942, 10 Game Turns total
Unit scale: division/1 unit

Mechanics are 3 Operation phases(Combat or Movement) and 2 Counter Phases(only Move).

title: Operation October Typhoon
description:
This is a Japanese wargame set in a hypothetical world war 3 during the cold war. This particular game concerns the battles of the south and central front in Germany and Europe.

Published by Tsukuda Hobbies.

title: Scarney 3000
description: Another member of the Farkel family (along with Cosmic Wimpout), Scarney 3000 uses 5 dice upon which the 2 and the 5 have been replaced with the word Scarney.  Points are scored for rolling Scarneys or for rolling 3 or more of a kind on one roll, but you're not allowed to score your roll until (a) you've collected at least 200 points for this series of rolls and (b) you've rolled at least one Scarney.  If you can't (or choose not to) score your current roll, you must re-roll all non-scoring dice, or all 5 dice if they're all used in scoring (e.g., a Scarney and four 3s).  First player or team to 3000 wins.

title: Murder Mystery Party: Murder at Tall Oaks
description:
Solve a Murder in an Evening With Friends! The Setting -- A festive birthday party at a stately country manor in New England on a crisp autumn evening. With no warning, a violent storm sweeps the grounds of the estate, but that's not the only violence afoot! After the storm subsided, self-made multi-millionaire Reginald Arcain went for a stroll to admire his sweeping grounds and check for damage. His body was later found near the grove of tall oaks that gives the manor its name. Who did him in? The successful publisher, the local physician, the beautiful maid, or someone else? By the time the evening's over, you'll know the truth!

Contents: Invitation, name tags, a map, clue booklets, the police report, complete instructions (and the solution to the crime), along with an optional CD-ROM

title: Fast Word
mechanisms: Pattern BuildingRoll / Spin and MoveTile Placement
description:
Fast Word is a card game where you create and swap words based on the throw of the die. With the simple goal of creating and keeping as many words as possible, other players try to take your words off the table and even right out of your hand! The winner is the player who has the most points from creating words in his/her possession when the game ends.

Contents: 
92 Letter Cards 
12 Wild Cards 
1 Playing Die 
6 Die Instruction Cards

title: Groucho's You Bet Your Life
description:
This new sensational quiz game gives you and your friends the opportunity of playing Groucho's You Bet Your Life Quiz Game in your own living room. -From the manual.

This trivia game is based on the Groucho Marx game show You Bet Your Life, which ran from 1947-61. Players (or teams) take turns asking trivia questions to the opposing team. The team answering make points not only for answering the question correctly, but also for spelling the answer in the alloted timeframe.

Game includes a mechanical countdown timer (60 seconds), trivia cards, an answer card, and cardboard letter tiles.

title: Gators!
description:
Player 1: Colonel, the friendly island nation of Unnarstan has been engulfed in revolution. The surviving members of the government have asked for American intervention. Your MEU (Marine Expeditionary Unit) is in the area, but there are no other forces available, and speed is of the essence, so the Marines have the ball. Your task is to fight your way into Unnarstan, occupy the capital, and bring the rightful government back there before you run out of supplies, which will happen in 15 days. You have advantages in numbers and quality, and you get to choose where your invasion will go in, but time and terrain are against you. Semper fi!

Player 2: Liberation! At last, our fair nation is free of foreign influences! Generalissimo, you have done well, but the imperialists are sure to react to our coup. Our armed forces are equipped with American weapons, so if they try to intervene, you can give them a taste of their own medicine. You must fight wisely, for we are outnumbered, but we know our own land and can defend it well. All we require is that you delay the invaders until their supplies run out, and then annihilate them at leisure. Death to the invaders!

Gators! is a 2-player wargame depicting a modern US Marines amphibious operation. This is a complete game with counters and maps (you must download my M8 map system separately). All you provide is a six-sided die.

title: Airborne!
types: Expansion for Base-game Modern Warfare Print & Play Wargame
description:
Player 1: Colonel, we got trouble. The nation of Hyrax has been invaded and overrun by forces from the neighboring nation of Koni. The United Nations has condemned the invasion and authorized the use of force, and your 82nd-Airborne ready battalion will be that force. You must make an immediate drop before the invaders can dig in, and reinforce yourself as needed later. Your goals are to free the capital of Hyrax and at least one other city from the invaders, and to capture at least one airfield so other UN forces can land there and finish what you've started. Those forces will start arriving in three days, which is also the amount of time your men can fight without resupply. Take 'em down! Airborne all the way!

Player 2: A dog's curse be on the United Nations and their resolutions! This territory belonged to our ancestors before the colonial imperialists divided it up, and it is ours again, and we will never leave it. The initial attacks were successful beyond our wildest dreams, and the whole country fell like dominoes. Now we must prepare for the counterattack that the UN and their lackeys will certainly launch. Most of our navy is at sea, searching for enemy ships that might bring invaders, and all the land approaches to our nation are well-guarded. But an attack could come from anywhere at any time, so you must be vigilant. Long live Koni!

Airborne! is a 2-player Expansion for Gators! depicting a modern US airborne operation. It uses the same basic rules as Gators!, and the same opposing force.

Expands:

    Gators!

title: Gators!: The New OPFOR
types: Expansion for Base-game Modern Warfare Print & Play Wargame
description:
The basic OPFOR used in Gators!, Airborne!, and Rangers! is based on American equipment from the 1950's and 60's. These new additions to the OPFOR are based on 1980's-vintage weapons from the Soviet Union, and they pack a lot more of a wallop. Most of these vehicles were exported to other nations, so your scenarios can still be based on brushfire wars anywhere in the world. I haven't written any scenarios, but this document includes a few general suggestions.

This new OPFOR provides vehicles and aircraft to replace their equivalent units in the basic OPFOR. You will still need that OPFOR to provide soldiers, light vehicles, and counters. The new units follow the standard rules for the game without modification.

title: S.A.B.O.T.
description:
S.A.B.O.T. stands for Simple Armored Battle in Oversized Terrain. It's a fast-moving futuristic land battle, meant to be played on a big game map. Each player spends his/her build points on various vehicles and soldiers, sets them up on map tiles from my M8 Map System, and fights until his/her foe has been wiped off the face of the earth.

This game's movement and combat rules are set up for large-scale battlefields with dozens of vehicles and soldiers. Ever want to fill a ping-pong table with game maps? This is your game. Got a door-sized folding table for game day? Play with a wide front and a shallow battlefield. Better yet, make a big square table from two folding tables. You can play this game on a small map, but it won't be as much fun.

S.A.B.O.T. is a complete game, with counters, markers, and maps. All you supply is a couple of d10's

title: Mythfire
description:
Jason! I know you're there! Hector's voice echoed across the valley. You can hide behind your goblins and skeletons, but I know you're there, and I am coming for you! He knew Jason could hear him, and he knew that his arch-enemy could not resist such a challenge. But how would he respond?

The answer wasn't long in coming. A huge boulder sailed across the valley and smashed into the ground just short of Hector's forces. One of his men went down screaming, hit by a sliver of rock. So Jason had a cyclops in his army, did he? Hector looked over to his minotaurs, roaring and waving their battleaxes. They would make short work of a cyclops, and then his ogres would begin the slaughter. He gave the hand signals for his line of mighty beasts to advance. This would be a day to remember!

If he had noticed the shadow that flitted over him, he might have looked up and seen Jason's roc beginning its dive on his forces...

Mythfire is a 2-player wargame of mythical beasts, mostly from Greek mythology. Players choose their armies from an array of creatures with varying abilities, then fight to the death.

title: Sark
description:
Components:

54 Letter Cards
A pad of Sark Squares (blank 55 grids)

Description:

A referee (or the players themselves) pulls letter cards one at a time from a randomized deck.  As each letter is pulled, players must place the letter on their own Sark square or 55 grid (hidden from other players).  After all 25 grid squares are filled, players score points based on how many 3, 4, or 5 letter words they made reading across or down.

3 letter words score 3 pts., 4 letter words score 5 pts., and 5 letter words score 7 pts.

title: Orbital Battle
description:
Orbital Battle is a wargame set in space. Two rival empires fight for control of the eight planets in a solar system, using land, air, and space units. What sets this game apart from similar wargames is that the planets move in their orbits, changing the game map every turn.

This two-player game comes with counters and map sheets. All you provide is a six-sided die, and pencils and paper for some very simple record-keeping.

title: Battleland Fantasy Miniature Gaming
types: Collectible Components Dice Fantasy Fighting Medieval Miniatures
mechanisms: Area MovementAuction/BiddingDice RollingPoint to Point MovementRole PlayingRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Battleland - Fantasy Miniature Game is a virtual based miniature game, in which players take control of an army, and do battle with one another. Battleland FMG is designed for internet play, whether it be in a play by post format, or a virtual tabletop. There are not any physical game pieces that are used, instead players use a map and images on their computers to play the game. The object of the game is to eliminate all of your opponents pieces, before they do the same to you.

BFMG also uses the popular method of collectible miniatures. All of the electronic figurines (e-figs) have a special quality about them, ranging from commons to rares. Additionally you will find that some commons are more common than others, or that some rares are very difficult to come across. Additionally there are gold e-figs. You only have a 1/25 chance to pull one of these from a booster pack.

title: Corporate
description:
Straightforward card game of office politics with a humorous tone.  This is a hand-produced game with hand-cut, black-and-white, laminated cards that come in a plastic trading card box adorned with a black-and-white cover label.

From the rules intro:

There was a time on this great planet of ours that wars were fought between nations and/or political factions for ideals, territory, money, or power.  Although the goals remain the same, wars are no longer fought by people in uniform.  Today's wars are fought by the groups that hold the real power in today's society.  Political factions are puppets to these entities, armies and military might are under their control.  These entities are referred to by a name that belies the fact that they have more power than any nation on the planet:  the Corporation.  The foot soldiers who slog forward daily to do battle on myriad fronts are no longer called privates, cadets or seamen.  Today's foot soldier defends his particular trench under the idealized rank of account representative, data input specialist, or simply, marketing representative.  His/her trench is also outfitted with the modern conveniences of a fax machine, a speed-dial telephone, and part interest in a secretary.  Today's wars are fought on the battlefield of office politics.

title: Power Monkeys
description:
An expansion for Ebola Monkey Hunt.

There's a new batch of ebola-infested monkeys in town, but this time they're on your side.  Includes 12 new monkeys with heinously powerful abilities and 18 new option cards.  May not be suitable for younger players.

Expands:

    Ebola Monkey Hunt

title: Emlyn Hughes' Team Tactix
description:
Emlyn Hughes Team Tactix is this game's full title and it's a vintage football board game promoted by the late great Emlyn Hughes and endorsed by the English FA.

The object of the game is to build a team of 11 top class players within the playing time of 90 mins.

The teams are drawn from a deck of glossy color picture cards representing the 11 first team players of the 21 best supported English league clubs and 4 top Scottish clubs of the mid 1980s.

The game was produced by Boss Leisure Ltd and is for 2 to 6 players Ages 8 and up

title: Verflixt und ausgebüxt
description: Six kinds of baby animals (dog, goose, cat, horse, sheep and rabbit) have fled from their parents. Every player has a card of each animal. Each animal is printed on a six sided dice. The starting player throws the dice. Every player has to search his/her card with the same animal as the dice and put it on the gameboard. The first player to do this can put his animal in the box, where the animal mothers live. The first player to put all his animals in the box wins.

title: Intimate
description:
From the box. The object for the game is for players to move forward and towards the center of the board, to enter the Erogenous zone, and ultimately to enter the Hot zone. When two players are in the small confines of the Hot zone at the same time this is considered to be the end of the game, as the excitement and the stimulation gained and given, in order to achieve this position, will make further concentration difficult,- if not impossible for anything other than making love, which is the real object of the game.

Players movements throughout the game are determined by the way they respond to either of three types of instructions read from cards picked at random. They could be asked to answer a question, do a forfeit, or perform an action, all of which are designed to stimulate all the senses and to prepare and encourage the players to bring the game to a satisfactory conclusion.

title: Rotundo
description:
The board contains 6 straight grooves running towards the centre and one going round the outer edge. (This outer edge groove is used only for the 12 balls at the start of the game). The game is played in the straight grooves in which the balls run down and are stacked.

The object of the game is to have 3 balls of your own colour stacked one on top of the other in a groove.

Two players each have 6 balls in their own colour. Each in turn places one ball in one of the six grooves. You can stack on top of your opponent's as well as your own balls. But no more than 3 balls are allowed in any one groove at this point. When all 12 balls have been placed, the players take it turns to move one ball from one groove to another: now there can be up to four balls in a groove.

You can only move one ball in your own colour and only if it is lying alone in a groove or uppermost in the groove, i.e. nearest the centre of the board. It is NOT counted as a move, however, if by moving a ball to another groove it happens that the balls in this groove are of the same number and in the same colour sequence as in the old groove before the ball left it.

A player has lost the game if he or she has no possibility of moving.

title: Pike City Arena
description:
It is over 200 years since the first of the terran colonists landed on the uninhabited and unsuspecting planet of Neo-earth. Humans have begun to establish a new history of wanton destruction and unbridled creativity. The Singularity rift that eventually will lead to the establishment of a utopia is centuries away in the future. The fledgling nation of U.S.N.A. originally set up by the North Americans of old earth is fast becoming one of the most powerful of the industrial states.

As nations formed and the population began to be settled the media was there to cover it. Whenever a settler put a spade in the ground, wiped out a species or did something horrible to another human being a camera was there. The media became the chronicler of the pioneering years, and more. To forget the hardships of day-to-day living the Neo-earthlings immersed themselves in all forms of entertainment sims, V.R. and finally real combat TV. Beginning as fighting matches between professional athletes it quickly evolved to include audience participation. Teams of home viewers roamed across elaborate battlegrounds beating the snot out of each other for the sake of entertainment. These teams eventually became fighting orders with their own particular combat styles. As long as TV audiences could see a New Texan housewife savagely mauling an accountant from Maine with a pain-wand each week real combat TV continued to be a success.

Nobody knows exactly when FENRIR (Fusion Engine Non-Robotic Intercept Raider) was invented. Originally developed as support for conventional army forces, they began to be used in the frontier areas and in civilian control situations. The executives of the NABC (Neo-American Broadcasting Corporation) weren't slow to adopt this new technology and use FENRIR in their real combat events. Unable to construct artificial battlegrounds of a sufficient size the media networks purchased the ruins of Harmony, the former capital of the USNA state of Piermont that had been destroyed during the conflict with the Ontarians. In this city-sized arena the combatants now range across the landscape in giant FENRIR machines dealing devastation to the opposing team(s). The ultimate televised combat sport is born!

In PIKE: City arena each person controls one of the four major real combat teams. The object is to crush the opposition while putting on the most entertaining show for the cameras.

title: Dash Hounds Game
description:
Just like the game's name...these four adorable, growable hounds really dash to win the race.  The dogs are small at the start of the race...but as the race progresses they grow longer and longer.  Unlike other races - the dog whose TAIL crosses the finish line first wins the game!

Players spin the spinner and move their dogs the appropriate number of spaces toward the finish line.  If the front legs of a dog should land on a colored space, the player whose dog matches that color must add a section to his dog.

title: Those Ragged Bloody Heroes. The Australian 7th Division at Gona: November 29-December 10, 1942
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description: THOSE RAGGED BLOODY HEROES depicts the bloody Pacific Island fighting on the northern coast of New Guinea. Here the Australian 7th Division has pushed the Japanese invader north in the long and bloody Kokoda Trail campaign. During the weeks prior to the battle for Gona, General Horii's defenders toiled long and hard to prepare a defensive death-trap that awaited the oncomingand unsuspecting Australian soldiers. Cleared fire-lanes, log bunkers and Japanese snipers await your men of the Australian 7th Division as you re-fight this tragic and controversial battle.

title: Klin Zha
description:
Klin Zha (Klingon chess) is similar to Earth chess in that it is an abstract board game between two players. Pieces move and capture opposing pieces like in chess. It is played on a triangular board with triangular spaces. Initial setup is free: players may arrange their pieces in any manner they choose within their section of the board.

Official website: http://www.tasigh.org/takzh/ (very outdated)

More recent website with extensive rule documents: http://www.klinzha.com

Online study tool: http://www.klinzha.com/study

On klinza.com, there's also a better ruleset that can be used with Zillions of Games. This ruleset is from 2010 and includes all twodimensional Klin Zha variants.

title: Axis Threat
description: Axis Threat is a  DTP wargame on the  German Counterattack at Gela in Sicily, 1943.

title: Bodycount in Laos
description: A DTP wargame on the Arvn (South Vietnamese army) incursion in Laos 1971.

title: Pocket Trivia: Gen-X 80s & 90s
description:
Trivia game about Generation X consisting of 52 cards with 16 questions on each card.  Lots of 1980s and 1990s trivia.

One player takes the top card from the deck and reads a question aloud.  The person to the card reader's left gives an answer.  If incorrect, the next player (clockwise) guesses, and so on.  If correct, the person who guessed correctly keeps the card; this person becomes the reader; he reveals the next card from the deck and reads it aloud.  If nobody guesses correctly, the answer is revealed and nobody gets the card.

Play continues until no cards are left in the deck.  The winner is the person who has the most cards.

title: Das Prestel Säulenspiel
description:
From Prestel web-site:

May it be an Ancient Greek Temple, or a Roman Palace; a Renaissance Cathedral or an Opera, the columns always had a special part in the architecture. In this tile placing card game you will control the money, the construction and placing of the columns to make a perfect construction.

title: It's a Small World Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: The object of the game is to be the first player to reach the clock after having five cards on their proper spaces on the board.

title: Vince Lombardi's Game
description:
Vince Lombardi's Game is a football simulation for two players that can be played on three levels. The basic game uses generic football teams. The intermediate game applies aggregate offensive and defensive ratings for the NFL/AFL team of each player's choice. The advanced game permits each side to use the individual stats for each NFL/AFL football player.

This game was published under the title Vince Lombardi's Game in 1970 and 1973, and under the name Be a Pro Quarterback! in 1971.

The latter variant is a bit of an oddity. The cover lists the maker as Sportsgames, the instructions list the maker as Sports Games, and the board lists the maker as RGI. Whoever published that edition, Be a Pro Quarterback! served as an odd placeholder between RGI's 1970 and 1973 Vince Lombardi football games. The rules of the game are the same as for the 1970 Vince Lombardi Game edition; only the players are different.

See also the 1967 version Fran Tarkenton's Pro Football by RGI, using the same plays and cards, but in a much higher quality format. (The cards are thick board, laminated, and backed with light felt. The plays board is full color on a stand, laminated so the play differentials can be listed by each play in grease pencil. That version also includes a down maker and a ten yard marker.)

title: First Down!
description: Before Tudor Games made its foray into a playbook-driven football game simulation, a Washington D.C. company known as TGD Games made its own version of a football game driven by play selection, First Down!. In it, two players call offensive plays and set offensive formations in order to drive down the field and score, or set defensive formations to prevent the offense from gaining ground.

title: 18 Wheel'n
description: 18 Wheel'n is a promotional piece published by Roof Enterprises and presented by George Transfer Inc. of Parkton, Maryland.  The object of the game is to be the first to get one's rig from their home city terminal to their destination terminal and back. Yellow spaces on the board require players to draw a card that can either help or hinder them.

title: Battlefield Command
description: Two players use tanks, helicopters, paratroopers, engineers, bridges, and infantry to achieve either full victory (elimination of an opponent's forces or Operations Command Center), or at least a tactical victory based on points should either of the main victory conditions no longer be achievable. Special advanced/tournament rules are also included.

title: Convoy Defender
description: One player takes on the role of a submarine force commander, leading a fleet of six submarines. The other takes charge of a convoy of nine destroyers and three convoy ships.  A hurricane and two tropical storms may also be added to increase game complexity. Victory conditions vary for each player: the convoy commander must eliminate the submarine fleet, while the sub commander need only reduce the convoy to a single ship.

title: Adventures of Sir Lancelot
description: This game is based on the NBC TV series of the same name. Two to four players compete in a spin and move venture to avoid pits, traps, a dragon, and the Black Knight as they head along the road to capture Camelot or Westbury Castle.

title: Baseball Action
description: Baseball Action uses a positioning and die rolling mechanism. Players have some latitude in positioning fielders and runners prior to the batter's die roll. The game may be played solo, with two players, or two teams of two.

title: Big Time Baseball
description:
Big League Baseball bills itself as The World Series of Baseball Games. It uses a curious dice-rolling mechanism that allows players to try to place their fly balls, ground balls, and bunts on a spot of the field least covered by opposing fielders. Strategy comes into play on offense in strategically allocating dice for a fly ball; on defense with positioning fielders to optimally cover the field.

No production date is given, but one of the Sid Sackson collection copies of this game was marked as being acquired in 1983.

title: Baseball's Greatest Moments
description: Baseball's Greatest Moments is a game in which each player's knowledge of baseball trivia is put to the test. Two to six players buy souvenirs and baseball memorabilia with the answer points awarded for correct answers. The winner must acquire 1500 points in souvenirs/memorabilia, 100 points in answer points, and answer a final challenge question in the last zone of the game board.

title: Capital Hill
mechanisms: Card DraftingHand ManagementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Capital Hill, as the title suggests, is a game of accumulating money through the political process. In the regular version, three to six players start with a randomly determined number of chips representing Senators and members of the House of Representatives. Each player directs their politicians to gain power and money by winning elections, holding onto power positions, and passing laws. Players are eliminated when they lose all their representation in the House and Senate. When only two players remain, the player with the most money is declared the winner.

A short version permits two to six players to compete for a fixed number of game rounds; again, the player with the most money at the end is the winner.

title: Coloption
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Coloption is also known as Col*ption.

From the rules:

COLOPTION is a fast paced adult game with some gaming elements familiar to generations of games players and new devices [...]. The object of the game, which is played on a geometrically designed game board, is to move your men from their home base to a goal. To do this, you must roll combinations of dice and color cubes and move your men through an exit triangle, hazard hexagon, safety zones, alien colors and goal paths. If that's not enough, there's also the danger of being 'bumped' by other players!

COLOPTION can be played by two to six players which immediately makes it more sociable than backgammon which is played as a twosome. A round is over when all of one player's men have either reached the goal or been bumped. A round usually lasts from fifteen to thirty minutes. Play can be for several rounds as in backgammon or for point totals as in bridge.

title: Conservation
description: In Conservation, players move their cars along the board's outer track, then the inner track, and then to their service station in the middle. Along the way, they face state fines and maintenance issues for their car. The game ends when a player reaches their service station, but the winner is the player with the most money at the end.

title: Corvette
mechanisms: Card DraftingHand ManagementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Corvette bills itself as the automobile maintenance and trading game. However, it somehow feels more like a Chevy advertising piece, as each player progresses from owning a Cavalier through a Celebrity, Caprice, and Camaro in their quest to be the first to own a Corvette and be free of debt.

2-6 players compete in an admittedly simplistic game: collect money by passing payday, then hope to avoid spending it all on car maintenance in order to buy a better car. Judicious selection of which pick up cards (coupons and special board advance cards) to keep in one's hand add a little strategy to an otherwise roll and move style game.

title: Counter All Terrorists!
description:
Counter All Terrorists challenges its players to defend against a series of terrorist attacks on the United States. The game may be played solitaire, or by up to six players. As the title suggests, the object is to counter terrorists' attacks on the White House, Pentagon, CIA, FBI, Air Force One, and many military bases and cities across the United States.

It is an unusual title in terms of historical insight, having been published in 1986 and embellishing its instructions with Albert Einstein's quote, imagination is more important than knowledge. The game treats a subject that few would take seriously at the time -- though, in hindsight, its designers also failed in imagination for the weights given the various terror targets.

title: Decisions
description:
From the publisher writeup:

DECISIONS is an exciting and colorful new drug-prevention board game that teaches youngsters to use their own personal power to manage relationships that put them at risk. Perfect for use at home or in school, DECISIONS uses hard hitting, real-life scenarios to help participants experience the anxieties and emotions associated with making decisions about relationships that involve drugs.

The game places up to six players in various real-life drug-related situations and encourages discussion for these scenarios.

title: Eccentric
description:
Eccentric features a search for the elusive billionaire Mr. Who (a takeoff on billionaire Howard Hughes). In a manner similar to Clue, players need to identify which city, hotel, and suite Mr. Who is in, along with which of his 5 disguises he is using.

From the game description:

Somewhere in the Western hemisphere, the eccentric billionaire, Mr.Who, is hiding. Suspicious and withdrawn, Mr. Who is elusive to the point of being almost invisible.

A Federal grand jury has just ordered Mr. Who to testify in court. Acting for the district attorney, three to six players are about to join in the exciting global search for the world's most fabulous recluse.

title: FutureStories
description:
From the game description:

Storytelling often revolves around the past. But there's another type of storytelling that we call FutureStories. Imagine playing a game where you talk about your hopes and dreams for the future. What do you want to be doing five years from now? What will the world look like in 100 years? [...]

FutureStories is easy to play and fun for all ages. There are no right or wrong answers. This game is based on your imagination, not intelligence, knowledge of trivia, or chance. And... it can be played anywhere.

title: Gambit
description:
Gambit is an abstract strategy game in the trappings of a war game. Players use jets, ships, amphibious vehicles, and rockets to seize an enemy goal square or eliminate their opponent.

The map for at least one printing is a bit of a curiosity. In it, the cover of the box shows a 10x10 board with alternating green and blue squares. The instructions note that the land squares are green and the sea squares are blue. However, the actual map provided is 10x16, has only black and white print on yellow paper, and uses the letters L and S to designate land and sea spaces. It would appear that the designer assumed he would be able to print color boards, but then had to fall back to a simpler black and white drawing printed on yellow paper.

title: Game of Love
description:
In this game, two to eight players compete by trying to out-romance each other. For the winner, the game notes, Your reward is collecting a KISS, a BEAR HUG, or a HEARTY HANDSHAKE from the lover of your choice. (We suggest the winning lover and the chosen one leave the room for this.)

While luck plays a factor in moving from the start space to the LOVE NEST goal, life experiences, memory, quick wit, and other factors can also help you advance. Some spaces call upon you to quote a line from a love poem (or complete a line for a provided rhyme) without repeating another player's answer. Others call on a player to correctly identify the eye color of the other players in the game. Still others feature bits along the line, If you think your legs are pretty, go forward one. If anyone doubts you, prove it or go back two.

title: Hat In The Ring
description:
Hat in the Ring is a throwback to an era when political party conventions still were perceived to hold an important role in the nomination of each party's candidates.

In this game, three to eight players compete for their party's nomination; however, in a classroom setting, additional roles such as Campaign Manager, Treasurer, etc. may be assigned to other participants. Players go through a series of primaries, then try to gain the required number of delegates at their party's convention to win on a given ballot. Delegates are won in blocks of 10; a player must therefore claim at least 660 out of the 1,300 delegates to win a given ballot and claim the nomination.

title: Is the Pope Catholic!?!
description:
IS THE POPE CATHOLIC !?! THE CATHOLIC NOSTALGIA GAME offers 2-6 players the opportunity to test themselves (in a somewhat humorous vein) on pre Vatican II Catholic doctrine.

While it can be played as a trivia game by non-Catholics, a handicap is definitely in order if one of the players is Catholic... and, especially, an older practicing Catholic.

The object of the game is to be the first player to ascend the Papal throne by completing a six-decade rosary around the board and advancing through the Church hierarchy.

title: Longball
description:
Longball is a stats-driven baseball simulation in which the players draw up their lineups from contemporary (to the publication date) Major League players, then play out the game with those players' stats weighting each die roll result.

At least three different editions of Longball were released. The first edition was in 1975 by Ashburn Industries and offered cards based on the 1974 season and projected 1975 rookies.  The second edition was in 1977 by Skor-Mor, and offered individual cards to represent each major league player's stats. The third was in 1979 by Ashburn Industries, which consolidated the player stats into 13 double-sided Team Roster cards.

The 1979 edition of Longball offers two levels of game play: the Master Game, an Advanced Master Game, and the Basic Game. Curiously, Ashburn gives the rules for the Basic Game last, reasoning, Since the majority of the people who buy LONGBALL buy it for the ultimate in baseball accuracy, we will begin with the explanation of the Advanced 'Master' version.

title: Lyle's Baseball Game
description:
In 1991, Sheryl and Steve Shrout took one of Steve's old game ideas and worked it into an actual game product. The game, Lyle's Baseball Game, draws its identity from Steve Shrout's middle name. It may be played solo or with two players. While the game is essentially a dice rolling contest, there are some amusing rules tossed in:

- No kicking dirt onto home plate.
- No spitting on the field.
- All rolls of the dice are final. No arguing with the dice.
- Seventh inning stretch optional, but suggested for couch potatoes.

title: Megacorp
description: In a manner slightly reminiscent of Milton Bradley's game of Life, two to six players choose whether to follow a path of self-employment and eventual sellout to Megacorp, or a university program that leads them to employment with Megacorp. However, both paths eventually converge and lead the players onto the path of a corporate takeover. When all players have reached either the Pyramid or the Over Budget squares, the player with the greatest total of Common Stock Shares becomes the Chief Executive Officer of Megacorp and wins the game.

title: Merit: The Catholic Game
description:
In Merit, two to four players work to build the six key properties (Church , Convent, Seminary, Catholic Charities, School and Foreign Missions) while maintaining their level of merits (700 points) and obtaining six of the seven sacraments. The first player to return home with the required six sacraments and at least 700 merit points after the six properties are built wins the game.

The question deck is filled with pre-Vatican II trivia, but also has cards that offer the player a chance to advance via deeds rather than answers (e.g., a card that allows the player to go to any square if they promise to say the rosary).

title: Offshore Oil Strike
description: Two to four players compete at exploring for oil, building platforms, and laying pipelines to bring the offshore oil back to the player's home company. Players take on the roles of either BP (Hull), Amoco (Bergen), Chevron (Rotterdam) or Mobil (Dieppe) in their quest for oil. As with other games focusing on offshore oil exploitation (e.g., Omnia's North Sea Oil), there is also the risk that storms will reduce production on, or eliminate, one's oil platforms. The first player to make $120,000,000 in cash is the winner.

title: Auction
description:
Players attempt to furnish a home as quickly as possible by acquiring furniture cards at auction or at shop prices.  They must also sell furniture by auction.

Rent has to be paid players acquire the required kitchen and bedroom furniture cards.  Furnishing a second bedroom produces rental income from a lodger.

The winner is the first player to have acquired a full set of furniture cards plus one other item.

title: Pol-A-Tics
description: In Pol-A-Tics, each player is assigned a platform of seven different issues that shows which position their candidate has taken on each issue. As with many election games, players choose a game duration prior to the start of game play. When that time has expired, players determine the popular vote winner in each state to allocate the electoral votes. Unlike actual elections, however, a tie in the popular vote for a state results in a split of that state's electoral votes, and the player with the most electoral votes is declared the winner.

title: Politics As Usual
description:
In Politics as Usual, each player takes on the role of a U.S. Senator and competes at getting himself/herself re-elected to the Senate. A player needs 5,000,000 votes in order to be re-elected. To gain these votes, players will need to cooperate with each other to pass Pork Barrel legislation and gain voter support, as well as work on their own to raise money.

The box cover illustrates some of the rather humorous cards in the game, some of which play off of events contemporaneous to the game's design. In one example, a player gains 700,000 votes due to their Trial Reform bill which, in actuality, creates a casino in the player's state specializing in bets on outcomes of celebrity murder trials.

title: Praise the Loot???
description: Praise the Loot??? is a product of the mid-1980s, when at least one prominent televangelist was found using his fun raising abilities for somewhat less than evangelical goals. In this game, 2-6 players race to the Pearly Gates. However, instead of amassing virtues - or even converts - the victor must acquire sufficient money and possessions in order to win.

title: Presidential Fever
description:
Presidential Fever allows players to face off against each other in a two Party contest. Two to four players may compete, though the three player game essentially calls for one player on one side to fill both the Presidential and Vice-Presidential roles. Players move around the board, capturing states with campaign funds. Players must also watch to maintain their credibility rating and to build either a liberal or conservative rating when appropriate. A lack of credibility keeps your party from winning a state; high credibility allows your party to overcome a liberal or conservative bias; liberal or conservative leanings provide financial rewards in many states.

Unlike most games based on the Electoral College system, Presidential Fever combines a number of contiguous low value states into a single region (e.g., Farm Belt, Border States, Mid-Atlantic, Deep South, etc.).

title: Profit & Loss
description:
Now here's a game from 1977 with a relatively short title and a mouthful of a game maker's name. The game is Profit  Loss ; the maker is Hollow Stump Bungalow Books  Games.

As the name suggests, two to six players buy and sell various items (antiques, art, securities, real estate, collectibles, etc.), trying to achieve a profit on each one. However, victory goes to the first player to reach $1,000,000, so at the end of the game it may be worthwhile to dump items at a loss to reach the finish first.

title: Pure Greed
mechanisms: Card DraftingCommodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and Move
description:
In 1971, CreaTek release a title called Pure Greed and subtitled it as, A Nasty Game for Nasty People. In truth, the game could have been subtitled, A Nasty Game *from* Nasty People, as it is essentially the same game that CreaTek marketed a few years earlier under the name Speculation.

Pure Greed is for two to six players. The object of the game is to amass the greatest wealth through property ownership. Players first compete at auction for the properties, then collect rents from each other or the bank as they land on owned properties. The game ends when the last purchase OPTION card has been purchased, at which point the player with the most money is the winner.

title: Running For President
mechanisms: Card DraftingHand ManagementRoll / Spin and Move
description: Running For President is a game that provides an odd mix of Primary, Convention, and General Election campaigns. Each player must obtain the necessary vote total in the Primary area in order to proceed to the Convention, then a higher vote total to proceed to the General Election, then a still higher vote total to break free and try to end the game. The player with the highest vote total wins, regardless of where they are on the board.

title: Slick Willie
description:
Long before Monica Lewinsky and cigars came to the fore on Clinton-based games, Slick Willie was a common theme in the Clinton-based game fare. As the designer goes on to note in his introduction, This game is based solely on my opinion. It's designed to make you laugh at all the hard times we've had over taxation and for all the aggravation, desperation and suffering we're all going to share in the months and years ahead.

In light of the game having come out before Clinton finished his first year in office, the prior 12 years of Republican presidencies, and the subsequent U.S. economic boom, it comes across in hindsight as one of the more mean-spirited Clinton games to hit the market.

The game is nominally for two to four players, though the designer notes that, you may play up to 6 players, for extra pawns use lose [sic] change. The object of the game is to amass and retain 270 electoral votes while trying to enter the White House.

title: The Big Board
description:
From the game description:

THE BIG BOARD is a game of stock investments, combining chance and skill. Two to six players move colored tokens around the board, and play the market. The object of the game is to make money, as much money as possible, before the game ends. To do this, players SPECULATE, buying low priced stocks that may rise in value, PROFIT-TAKE, selling stocks for more than they cost, and EARN DIVIDENDS on the stock they own. [...]

Investors must watch the market's movement and make the right choice at the right time to get the most return on their investments. Test your skill against the ups and downs of the stock market on THE BIG BOARD.

title: The Big Campaign
description: The Big Campaign is a game for either two or four players. In a fashion reminiscent of Monopoly, players gain the electoral votes of a given state by landing on it and buying it. Opponents who land on one of your states must pay a penalty for campaigning in that state. However, there are Campaign issue cards that can allow you to gain a state for free, or have a state wrested from your control and placed back up for grabs.

title: The Mileage Game
mechanisms: Card DraftingHand ManagementRoll / Spin and Move
description: In The Mileage Game, players compete in trying to travel the greatest number of miles using the least number of gas tokens. The game ends when one player has traveled 2000 miles; however, the winner is the player who has achieved the best Miles Per Gallon (MPG) score.

title: The Narc Game
description:
The Narc Game strikes an unusual, and perhaps unintentional, balance between the blatantly drug-sympathetic Dealer McDope and the just say no approach of Decisions. From the lid description above, it would appear to be a strictly anti-drug game. Yet, curiously, actual game play comes across more as a beat the system game than one of social value education.

Two to six players compete, with the object of the game being to accumulate the fewest arrests. The game ends when all players have successfully made it from the START square to the HOME square. Along the way, players gain and lose money in various drug deals, and must try to avoid a stint in the Criminal Justice system that costs them money and sends them back to START.

The joke of the game, of course, is that it is almost impossible to go from START to HOME without getting sent back to START.

title: Traffic Jam
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and MoveTile Placement
description: In Traffic Jam, players try to reach their respective chosen destinations with a combination of both strategic road sign placement and good die rolls.

title: Gekitsui oh
description:
This is an Japanese air combat game set in the Pacific during World War 2.

Geki tsui oh means Flying Ace (word to word: Shooting down aircraft expert).

title: Romance of the Three Kingdoms
description:
This is a Japanese wargame set during the time of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms era in Chinese history.

the game is a first attempt to this theme in wargame format in Japan.
And very famous one for its own sake.
At game starts, players pick three character counters randomly.
Yes, this is the Oath at Peach Garden for each player.
Game include over 100 characters.
So, the game is basically a Grow fast type multi players game.

title: Helios
description:
Helios (subtitled The Game of the Gods) is a chess-like game loosely inspired by classical mythology.

The king for each side is Helios, the sun god, and nine other pieces on each side represent the planets and the gods they are named after.  Three other pieces on each side represent Earth's Moon and its orbital nodes.  The pieces are made of a plastic called Tenite (according to the rulebook) and resemble chess pieces topped with the traditional planetary symbols.

The pieces have movement powers reminiscent of those of chess pieces, but with some differences: several pieces have more than one way to move, one mode of movement - N squares at a time in any direction, repeated 3 times - is not found in standard chess, and generally speaking pieces are limited to moving a number of spaces equal to their relative position from the Sun plus 1 (e.g., the Earth piece can move 4 squares at a time).

The board is a 20x20 grid with a block of 40 unplayable spaces in the center.  There are special starred spaces on the board which are used by the pieces with weaker standard movement (Mercury and Helios) to teleport around the board.

Pieces are captured by landing on them.  The object is to put the opponent's Helios in checkmate (or total eclipse).

In addition to the rules themselves, the rulebook includes information on the gods and planets represented by the pieces.

title: Sailboat Race Game
description: Simple roll and move game for boys and girls Ages 4 - 8

title: Super Plug
description:
You don't know the power of the plug!

Cards and rules in an envelope, following the Cheapass design philosophy.  The premise is that the players are trying to get the landlord's attention by plugging up the toilet in their apartment with anything they can find on the theory that, while the toilet is being fixed all the other things wrong with the apartment will be fixed also.  Having lived in off-campus apartments during college, I can relate.

Each player is given a playing mat with a picture of a toilet on it and is dealt one card.  On each player's turn they may draw from 0-2 cards and play one card, either on their own toilet or another player's.  The winner is the first person to exactly reach a predetermined level of points worth of stuff in their toilet (20 points for a two player game, 18 for three, etc.)  Some cards are worth negative points and are played on opponents.  That person must then remove that many points worth of stuff from their toilet.  If they don't have any cards small enough (say a -2 card was played, for instance) they must discard a larger card (Baby Brother [+5] for instance) and accept the greater loss--no making change allowed.  There are also Pet cards.  While a player has a Pet card next to their toilet they cannot win even if their toilet is full to the required score--the landlord doesn't allow pets.  They may discard the Pet card, but this counts as their entire action for the turn and they may not draw or play any other cards.

Each copy of Super Plug also comes with 5 blank cards.  Players are encouraged to create cards of their own.

title: Taiheiki
mechanisms: Area Control / Area InfluenceArea MovementDice RollingSimulation
description:
This is a Japanese wargame on the Nanboku-cho period and simulates one of the most dynamic and important periods in Japanese history.

It uses an area movement system. This game has cult status among Japanese wargamers as one of the best games representing the era, and the system is also used in the designer's later games Koetsu gunki and Warriors of God.

Components (First edition):

    1 Rule book
    1 Map (510x360 mm)
    1 Counter sheet (128 Counters)
    8 Six side dice

title: View-Master Grand Prix
description:
The game is played on a  4 x 3 board depicting a race track.  The track has grid spaces on it and players roll dice to move (one space for each number).

If a car lands on a space with a picture on it, the player has to pick up the Viewmaster viewer and place a reel in it.  They then roll a die and advance the reel by the number shown.  Peering in the viewer, they will see a 3D scene that will either give them an advantage or a handicap.

The game came with four Matchbox cars; these are now very rare collectibles.

title: Små kloka barn på piratäventyr
types: Children's Game Educational Nautical Pirates Trivia
description:
The little smart pirate shall go from the sinking ship to the island there the pirates treasure is located. On his way to the island the pirate has to answer some questions. The right answer can give him one or several gold-coins. But on his way there is also dangerous things that want to stop the pirate from reaching the island. Like the dreadful pirate captain, the evil octapussy and the hungry shark.
The pirate with the most gold is the winner

title: Hydra!: The Ultimate Starcruiser?
description:
Hydra! (subtitled The Ultimate Starcruiser?) was one of Grenadier's Midi Games (sic) or The Great Little Games Line, depending on whether you believe the box or the rules.  This was a small line of games somewhat larger than a typical mini-game of the day.

Hydra! could reasonably be described as Ogre in Space. As in Ogre one player has a single huge unit while the other has many small units. Here the large unit is the eponymous Hydra, which has phasers, proton torpedoes, energy sapper discs, a gyro-de-stabilizer, a molecular structure distorter, and a force field projector.  The other player gets frigates, battle cruisers, larger battle cruisers, and mine sweepers. Damage for both sides is marked off on record sheets.

The Hydra player's goal is simply to destroy as many enemy ships as possible, but players are invited to make up other scenarios and some extra counters are provided to facilitate this.

7001 in the Great Little Games Line. The back of the first (only?) printing's box came with the sheet for the game Journey and listed its part number also as #7001. This same sheet also came with the actual game Journey as well. However, the sides of the boxes had Hydra! as 7001 and Journey as 7002.

title: Starcross
description:
Starcross is a relatively simple strategic science fiction game.

The board is made up of a number of hexagonal sections, the number in use depending on the number of players and the desired length of the game.  Each section has a number of star systems which produce varying amounts of credit, and have no other characteristics.  Players use their controlled credit each turn to build or upgrade their ships.
Ships have two characteristics, movement speed and combat strength - players choose the values of these by how much they spend.

Interest is added by the technological advances which can be purchased.  Some of these are permanent, such as Hyperdrive, which lets one ship per turn move an unlimited distance, or Capture, which lets you capture enemy ships if you have a 3:1 advantage, while some are temporary, such as Force Field, which protects a system for one turn.  (Capture will sound familiar to players of Flying Buffalo's Starweb play-by-mail game - most of the Starweb abilities are in fact reproduced here.)  Each advance can only be purchased a given number of times per game (depending on the number of players), so players will be forced to use different mixes of abilities.

The object of the game is to control a given quantity of credit production.

title: Små kloka upptäcker rymden
description:
The task for the little smart astronaut to take his spaceship as fast as he can to the moon.
The journey is filled with tricky questions. The answers will be rewarded with stars. The stars can be used to buy extra fuel or pay fines if he took the wrong way.

First to the moon is the winner.

title: Napoleon at Chattanooga
description:
This is a self-published game that can be downloaded for free at several sites over the Internet (including the designer's site, so this is not a violation of any type).

From the introduction in the rulebook:

Napoleon at Chattanooga is a painstakingly-researched, meticulously accurate simulation of Napoleon's campaign in the Tennessee Valley.  It is also a two-player game of exploration and conquest in the Solar System, which is also painstaking but not necessarily accurate.  This game is the first in the ACW (Advanced Chart Wars) series and is also considered part of the ongoing GBoTGCN (Great Battles of This Guy Called Napoleon) series by most of the people working in the stockroom.

title: Googolplex
description: 36 tiles make up this maze game with a twist.  The preprinted maze on the tiles show you the path to the other side.  If you come to a dead end, your turn ends.  On your next turn, you turn a tile and continue on your path.  A very clever game with no dice, cards, or spinners.

title: Torpedo Game
description:
Summary from the box ...

It's a fast paced battle at sea.  It's an action packed game for the whole family.

Instructions (from box lid) ...

To Set Up
Each player places six of the steel balls in the loading slot of his torpedo gun.  Each player sets up three ships in the notches at his end of the game board.

To Play
The object is to knock over the opponent's ships with the torpedoes (the steel balls).  First, turn the torpedo tubes to the direction of the enemy ship, by using the target finder through which you can sight the ship.  Then, fire the torpedoes by pressing the trigger.  Players may rotate turns or fire simultaneously.  Each player totals his score for the ships he has sunk.  100 is a perfect score.

title: Gundam Zeta A.E.U.G.
description: This is a Japanese wargame on ground combat in the anime world of Gundam Zeta, this game focuses on the battles of the AEUG faction (the good guys).

title: Pokémon Battle Disc Competition
description:
From the Rulebook:

Select and shuffle up to FOUR Battle Discs at a time. Place them into the plastic ball and shake it. Open it and slam down the ball-half containing the discs. The other players do the same. Once all the players have their pile of discs in front of them the battle begins.

Each player places the discs in a straight line in the order that they have come out of the plastic ball. Place the matching figure next to the disc.

Starting with the first disc, each player flips their disc into the air. How it lands determines who wins the battle and puts the other player's figures out of the competition. The disc with the greatest power rating (number of stars) wins. A tie of the highest numbers has to be flipped again until there is a winner.

Play continues until all the figures are defeated except for the remaining one who is the champion.

title: Muggins!
types: Abstract Strategy Bluffing Math Number Puzzle
mechanisms: Dice RollingPattern BuildingRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Add, subtract, multiply, and/or divide three (3) numbers shown on the dice to produce an answer.  Try to make an answer that helps build and run for you (bonus points) or blocks your opponent's run.  Throw in a bluff or challenge your opponent's answer as you try to outwit and outmaneuver each other in this analytical aerobic workout for the mind!

http://www.educationallearninggames.com/how-to-play-muggins-knock-out-game-1.asp

2002 Mensa Select

Re-implemented as:

    Opps

title: Knock-Out
description:
Add three numbers together to make a total.  Then use your best thinking skills to break that total into its parts to knock your opponents off the board while capturing numbers for yourself!  From the mathematically challenged to the mathematically gifted,  KNOCK-OUT!, with its multi-leveled play, is guaranteed to make math fun again!

http://www.educationallearninggames.com/how-to-play-muggins-knock-out-game-2.asp

title: Monkey Trouble
description:
A huge catastrophe has happened during the reception that the Countess organized in her garden! Koko the little monkey has escaped and stolen panties and other sexy underwear from the drying line. Here he is, giving them to the guests who are shocked by this dreadful vision !

The Countess is beside herself and orders her servant to quickly do something otherwise he will be fired. But Alfred is too old to catch the monkey ! So he decides to ask the many participants to go into the living room after he gets back the panties that are being given out Koko. Hopefully when he eventually catches Koko, he will be able to get several pairs of underwear back simultaneously. Anyway hell have to make sure that at 5 oclock, no more guest still has a piece of underwear in hand or he loses his job.

title: Glücks-Käfer-Baum
description:
Beetles tree putting play game, with several play variants.  Good for 2 players. Beetles have to get cherries, but there are not enough for all players. It becomes particularly exciting, if the luck beetles come into the play!

Contents:  1 three-part tree, 12 beetles, 2 luck beetles, 10 yellow and 10 green plugs, to 6 valuation disks (everything in wood)

Ages 3 and up

title: Matchbox Traffic Game
description:
Each player has a Matchbox car which is moved on the board.  Players travel between destinations to accumulate mileage.  The center of the board features a rotating turntable and rotating traffic signal.  The turntable changes shortcut paths across the center of the board when it rotates, the traffic signal changes game play.

Ages 8 - 14

The original game included two Matchbox cars; examples of the game that still include the cars and the boxes are highly collectible.

title: Tokugawa Ieyasu
description: This is a Japanese wargame on the famous battles of Tokugawa Ieyasu, the Shogun who founded the Tokugawa shogunate when he won the battle of Sekigahara.

title: Genpei War: Rise and Fall
description:
The theme is the Genpei war (1180-1185) leading to birth of the first Shogunate, Genji or Minamoto.

The game was designed by Makoto Nakajima of Taiheiki fame.
The system was derived from that game and can be played in 30 minutes.

title: The Big Match Football Game
description: Game of Australian Rules Football. The Big Match Football Game from 1991 closely simulates the real thing. Role the dice and move the football down the field by hand or foot. Marks are contested, scores kicked, tackles laid, free kicks given, ball-ups ruled, reports made etc.. Tackle cards and play cards provide the umpires decision on contests.

title: BrickMech
description:
(From the BrickMech site:)

BrickMech is a d6-based game where Mechs built of LEGO bricks vie for ultimate control of the battlefield. Constructed in a unique modular system, Mechs can scavenge parts blown off other Mechs to improve their stats. The game is designed to be a rich gaming experience that's simple to play.

title: Lucky Town
description: 1946 game from Milton Bradley. A simple roll and move game. Also known as the Build a Happy Home Game.

title: Orient Expedition
mechanisms: Co-operative PlayDice RollingModular BoardPick-up and DeliverRole PlayingRoll / Spin and Move
description: Use game cards and board pieces with your Orient Expedition LEGO sets to overcome challenges, defeat villains and discover hidden treasure.  Each player controls a unique LEGO character, with specific speed, luck, and strength attributes.  Move around the board, collecting items to enhance your character's abilities so that you can overcome obstacles.  Combat LEGO villains that stand in your way.  The challenges and obstacles are essentially a scripted Indiana Jones type storyline.  When you have overcome the final challenge, all players win.  You can rearrange your game board and sets to create all-new adventures.

title: The Sweeney
description:
It has a yellow and black duo-toned drawing of Regan and Carter on the box, and claims to be 'an exciting game for four players'.

The game parts are: a board, a scoreboard, 16 small cards and 4 small plastic figures representing The Villains (typical Burgler Bill 'swag' type figures) and The Sweeney (Policeman blowing a whistle). Oh, and two dice.

The idea is that you work in pairs, two players are the villains, and two are The Sweeney. You have to meet up with your partner at randomly designated places on the board for a raid. When you successfully raid a location you get points to add to the scoreboard, and the winner is the first up the scoreboard to number 14.

title: The Nags Head Board Game (Only Fools and Horses)
description:
Mange Tout Rodney, get down the apple  pears, get your cocktail umbrella  jellied eels ready 'cos you won't believe your mince pies when you see what's going down in the Nag's Head pub.

Yes, it's time for a knees up in the Nag's head. Meet the gang at the bar, choose a character  be the first to collect all the drinks. On the way, avoid being barred  take a chance on the quiz night or, if you're feeling lucky, try one of Del's Dares.....he who dares...wins!

Your amazing Nag's Head Game Collector's Tin contains:
x1 playing board, x1 dice, x1 bag, x6 character playing tokens, x6 character game cards, x20 happy hour cards, x36 drink tokens, x20 Del's dares cards

title: Angelina Ballerina's Dancing Game
mechanisms: ActingDice RollingRole PlayingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStorytelling
description:
Roll the dice and move around the board. When you land on an Angelina Ballerina space, draw a dance card, and then stand up and perform the depicted ballet step or position. The first person to collect 4 dance cards wins, but first they must perform a ballet routine using all 4 steps or positions shown on their cards.
Also includes a Memory variant in the rules, using the dance cards.

title: Angelina's Dress-Up Card Game
types: Action / Dexterity Card Game Children's Game Memory Novel-based
description: This is a collection of variants of 4 popular card games with an Angelina Ballerina theme. Included are themed variants of: Memory, Crazy 8s, Go Fish, and Spoons.

title: Maisy Game
description: Players spin to claim the objects that match their playing board.  The first to get all 7 is the winner.

title: Bouncin' Bunnies
types: Action / Dexterity Animals Children's Game Real-time
description: Load different small colored plastic bunnies into the game board and turn it on.  The board rotates, and the bunnies randomly pop/hop/bounce up several feet into the air, while the players try to catch them in hand held baskets.  Different colored bunnies are worth different numbers of points, so players must choose to either compete for the rare high valued bunnies, or grab a lot of the lower valued bunnies instead.

title: Bug Bingo
description: A humorous bug themed variant of Bingo, where players roll two dice and cover any of the pictures on their cards that match the images shown on both dice.  Certain die rolls force pictures to be uncovered.  Get all four corners covered, or four-in-a-row in any direction, and you win.

title: Sight Words Bingo
