title: Trivial Pursuit: Celebrity Edition – Bite-Size
types: Expansion for Base-game Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game Trivia
description:
An expansion for Trivial Pursuit with 600 new questions about celebrities. Also playable without the game board, using the special starred dice included in the box.


This is another in the Bite-Size range of Trivial Pursuit games. It is intended as a portable travel game. The game is packaged in a wedge (piece-of-pie) shaped box.

The game does not feature a game board, and thus, there is no roll-and-move mechanic. Instead, players roll the color-coded die, and answers a question matching the color rolled. If a player correctly answers a question, he may go for a wedge by answering another question in the same category. If he does so, he keeps that card. If the player answers a question incorrectly, it is the next player's turn. Play ends when a player has collected six cards/correctly answered 12 questions.

title: Funny Ha-Ha!
description:
From the publisher's site (freely translated from Finnish):

The incredibly funny joke game!

Funny Ha-Ha will make you laugh in a matter of seconds! Even though to win this game you are supposed to not laugh. The game contains hundreds of jokes of different categories; animal jokes, restaurant jokes, Swedish jokes, school jokes, hospital jokes... Tell a joke, make up a funny face, play the laugh track. The main point is to make your opponents laugh and collect the points. Funny Ha-Ha is a true source of laughter for the whole family. All you need is a cassette player and a hilarious gaming session can begin. But remember, if you are planning to win... DON'T LAUGH... DON'T EVEN SMILE!

title: Renegade Legion: Centurion – Harbingers of Death
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
The 13379th legion the Harbringers of Death is one of the most renowned units in the Terran Overlord Government military.  They also became the first all male unit in the TOG forces.

Because the Harbringers of Death is known to this day as the most loyal unit in Caesars army they have won the enviable assignment of testing new equipment under battle field conditions.  As a result of so many years in this capacity the unit can claim the distinction of having fought more varied opponents than any other unit.

The Harbingers of Death are the most fanatically loyal TOG unit in existence. Elite, battle hardened troops tremble at the thought of serving with them. World populations panic at news of their approach. They have never known defeat. The First Cohort of The Harbingers of Death are the elite of this celebrated unit. Included in this scenario pack are unit personality profiles, unit history, combat readiness, and 15 scenarios.

Expands:

    Renegade Legion: Centurion – Blood & Steel

title: PanGaea
description:
The game's tag line is A Game With A Past!

In the game, players move around Pangaea, collecting Destination Cards, Dino Dollars and discs. The goal is to be the player with the most Dino Dollars at the end of the game, which happens when one player collects eleven Destiny Cards and returns to the start/finish square.

However, it's not as easy as it sounds, as randomly-drawn Destiny Cards can affect gameplay.

title: Cruz de Ferro
description:
FREE World War II miniatures wargame in Portuguese, with some scenarios, modules, new rules, and expansions. It covers the following scales:

1/300
15 mm
25/28mm
1/72

Available Modules

Cruz de Ferro - Core Rules
Crescendo of Battles - English, French and Italian Armies
Sol Nascente - Japanese and Chinese Armies
Construtor de Cenrios - Rules for scenario design
Avies - Planes core rules
TigerFibel - Booklet about Tiger Tank
FEB - Brazilian Expetionary Force
Panzerleader - Rules for 1/300

News

New Rules are on the way. 2nd Edition in end of may 2009

title: Swizz
description: Swizz players use card decks to move their playing pieces around the board. As in its sister game, PanGaea, players must collect eleven special cards - in this case, they're called Resort Cards. When a player has collected eleven Resort Cards and lands on the start/finish space, the game ends. The player with the most points wins the game.

title: Mixies Card Game
description:
From the deck insert:

Mixies Card Game is challenging and delightful.  Your child will have hours of fun matching up the FRONT, MIDDLE, and BACK of each of these Things That Go, or shuffling the cards and combining them to make all sorts of whimsical mixed-up things on wheels.

title: Sunken Treasure
description: In Sunken Treasure, the player's deep sea diver has to leave the salvage ship to recover a gold bar from a chest at the bottom of the sea.  The player must then return the gold bar to the salvage ship.  Components include: a board, 5 wooden gold bars, five wooden play pieces, a card spinner, and a card ship.  The rules are printed in box lid

title: Grey Storm, Red Steel
description:
Grey Storm, Red Steel is a set of miniatures rules for small-unit tactical combat on the Eastern Front in World War 2. The scale of the game is a 1:1 representation of men and equipment. Time scale is one game turn equals 2 and a half minutes; ground scale is 1 inch equals 10 meters. The miniatures are mounted in multiples on bases that represent rifle teams (3-4 figures), light machine gun teams (2 figures), leaders (1 figure) and weapons teams (2-4 figures depending on the weapon). Tanks and vehicles are mounted singly. Infantry units are made up of two or more rifle teams and zero to two light machine gun teams.

The rules work very well for representing actions on a platoon or company scale. The rules are best for infantry actions. The rules for tanks are not very detailed: one die roll to see if a hit is made, another for the result based on a comparison of the penetrative ability of gun firing with the overall armor quality of the target. However, they tend to give as good an end result as more complex rules. Anti-tank weapons range from the PzB38/39 and PTRD AT rifles to massive 128mm and 152mm AT guns.

GSRS provides rules for hidden set up, pre-battle recon, weather, command control, and target location that can be used to make challenging game scenarios. There are also some chrome rules for things like Panzer Aces, Heroes of the Soviet Union, and civilians in the combat zone. The rules also cover the use of cavalry and air support.

The rules includes a lot of information about unit organization, AFV data, and aircraft data. There is also a section detailing the differences between Soviet and German tactics and capabilities.

GSRS is a somewhat obscure and underrated set of miniatures rules that provides a great deal of flavor and compares very well to tactical boardgames like Squad Leader, ASL, and the Advanced Tobruk (ATS) series.

title: The Hammer's Slammers Handbook
description:
Vehicle designs  technical specification plus an easy play gaming system.  Approved by David Drake - author of the Hammer's Slammers books.

This little 7x9 soft cover color booklet combines two aspects often associated with more traditional miniature war games, detailed unit organizations and quick play miniature rules.  20 pages are devoted to technical details, vehicles, and uniform references.  While the remaining 20 pages are quickly play set of 1:1 war game rules.

Forces are composed of Tactical Units graded on quality (elite, veteran, regular, or untrained).  Each turn players receive a variable number of Leadership Points based on the quality of their commanders.  Standard miniature movement rules and some unique combat mechanics based on a d6 complete the basics for these rules.

Suitable for play in any scale: 6mm, 10mm, 15mm, 25mm, or perhaps a variant to the Mayfair classic.

title: YARI
description:
From the manual:
Welcome to the world of YARI - one of the lost wonders of the earth!
From the cradle of civilization to the dawn of civilized man, many collective societies have risen and fallen, leaving only mysterious traces of their cultures, struggles, and wisdom. Like all civilizations, they, too, had much to teach the generations that followed, but those secrets have remained lost in sand and stone, long forgotten... until YARI.
YARI is not just a game.
YARI is a way of thinking.
YARI is logic, strategy, and wisdom.
YARI is a secret that you, too, can share, an arcane pathway into the development of the mind.
YARI is a universal language without words, without sound.
YARI links your mind to your opponent's - a contest of wills.

YARI is... basically... Sorry! using shells for dice and a few fairly nice bits.

title: Pyramid Power Game
description: The game is played on a 3D plastic pyramid with holes on the faces.  Players construct continuous lines (or Lifelines) of pegs of the same color from the bottom of the pyramid to the top.  The line may be on or cross any face of the pyramid; it may even stretch all the way around the whole pyramid.  The first player to construct such a Lifeline is the winner.

title: Fliegende Untertassen
description: Using memory and alien movement (via dice rolls), players try to collect as many of the 36 face down tiles (UFO parts) and aliens from the board.  Big UFOs in mostly the same colors that hold the most aliens score higher.  The winner is the player with highest total score when all the tiles have been collected.

title: La Bataille de Friedland
Austerlitz
Lügen-Kniffel
description: Yahtzee with a twist.

title: Im Wassergarten
description: This is a game of perception. At the beginning the 48 photo tiles are laid out to form a water garden. All tiles must be completely visible. They show all that one would find in a pond: Frogs, fish, sea-roses and other aquatic plants in the most multicolored colors. After the water garden is laid out, all players receive a tablet on which four pictures are shown. The players must find the pictures of their own tablet faster than the fellow players.

title: Antipod
description:
Antipod is a connection game with unequal goals played on the two halves of a sphere.

Antipod is played on two equally sized hex boards, typically with six cells per side. The board is set up with a black piece in the center of each half, forming Blacks antipodal goals, and white pieces placed at the six corners of each board, forming Whites handicap pieces.

Black wins by forming a chain of black pieces between the antipodal goals of each board half. White wins by preventing a Black win. This amounts to completing a cycle of white pieces around at least one of Blacks antipodal goals. Exactly one player must win.

title: La Bataille de Valmy
description: Simple variation of the Napoleon's Last Battles system depicting the Franco-Prussian engagement at the start of the Revolutionary War on 20 September 1792. Colorful 78x56cm map at a scale of 400m per hex, and double-sided units at regimental and battalion level. The game has simple formation rules, but is low-complexity with no facing rules. The 19-page rulebook, in French, contains historical commentary, OBs, examples of play, but only 8 pages of actual rules. Not much chrome, for instance to simulate the famous French cannonade!

title: Vimeiro
Battle of Salamanca
description: Low-to-medium complexity grand tactical treatment of Wellington's first offensive victory over the French under Marmont on 22 July 1812. Rules include facing and morale in a 10-page rulebook with a page of charts. Ground scale is 500 yards per hex, and troop scale is brigade. 120 playing counters and 120 markers; map 17x22, reminiscent of SPI. This is the sister game of Battle of Vittoria.

title: Fire & Steel
description:
Fire and Steel is GDW's set of rules for 15 mm Napoleonic miniatures.  The rules set provides a complete rules for conducting battles in Europe between 1808 and 1858.

This rules system is ideal for the beginning miniatures wargamer.  The rulebook is only 6x9 in size with the text printed in single column to a page.  They are concise an easy to understand while still modeling the effects of warfare accurately.

The only thing the rules are a little thin on is command and control.  The system assumes that all units activate orders automatically.  However, this is a good thing for beginning wargamers (less to think about your first time out!).  You can always add your own CC rules.

GDW also included a 6x9 organization book and charts in their boxed set.  These detailed the organization, quality, capabilities, and how to mount the figures for each unit that fought in Europe during the Napoleonic era.  Again, this makes the system easier for the beginner to learn as they don't have to do a lot of research.

Fire and Steel regulates the size of bases and terrain on a pure ground scale.  The board played on depicts terrain at a ground scale of 1 = 25 yds.  The size of the minis bases are dependent on how much frontage the unit occupied, not abstracted like other minis games.

Also see GDW's sister rules set called System 7 Napoleonics.  For the most part, the two rules sets are identical.  Really, the only difference between the two is the System 7 rules allow counters to replace miniatures.

title: Footy!
description:
FOOTY! is a table-top simulation of the game of Australian Rules Football.

FOOTY! includes all the charts and tables needed to play the game, as well as a sample scoresheet.  The game is being re-published by Hot Stove Games under license from Valgames, and will be initially available in electronic format.

Players roll the dice on the Play Chart to determine what type of play is happening on the field.  Additional rolls are then necessary to test player skills, team strength, or other ratings in play.  Goals and behinds are scored by rolling the dice against the chosen player's scoring ratings.

All seasons from 1993 to 2004 will be available for owners of the game to purchase.  Additional seasons will be made available as data becomes available for them.

title: The BibleMan Adventure
types: Adventure Children's Game Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme Religious
mechanisms: MemoryPick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description: In this adventurous board game, BibleMan and his friends are on a mission to rescue children that have been tricked by enemies of God. Players select a hero card and matching token to battle the Bad Guys while traveling quickly through the town of Shatzville in an attempt to save the children. The first player to rescue 6 kids, deliver them safely to the town church and race back to the BibleMan Cave is the winner! The BibleMan board game is actually 2 games in 1. Instructions are included for both a Basic Game Ages 3 - 6, and an Advanced Game Ages 7 and up and allows for both age groups to play at the same time.

title: The Zany Zoo Adventures Of Tennessee Tuxedo
types: Animals Children's Game Humor Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Help Tennessee, a wise-cracking penguin, his dim-witted pal, Chumley and Mr. Whopee chase and capture the mice that have overrun Megalopolis Zoo.

A simple spin and move board game by Transogram based on the Tennessee Tuxedo animated TV series.

- 12 playing pieces 
- 31 cards 
- 1 spinner 
- 1 gameboard 
- Box with instructions

title: Pipeline: The Game of Oily International Trade
Infernal Machines
types: Card Game Deduction Humor Industry / Manufacturing Memory
description:
From the publisher:

Each player is a quality assurance agent in a factory that makes goofy gadgets from widgets of questionable quality.  But they're no ordinary inspectors -- they're SECRET quality assurance agents with their own agenda!  The object of the game is to ship as many of your own widgets as possible while scrapping other players' widgets so you can secretly resell them.  The catch is that if another player exposes your secret inspector identity (which can be deduced from which items you are allowed to take off the assembly line), you're fired!  The player with the biggest widget hoard at the end of the game wins.  Optional rules adjust the ferocity of gameplay and the difficulty of deduction.

title: WTF (Where's The Fun?)
types: Card Game Collectible Components Humor Party Game
description:
From the publisher:

WTF is, on the surface, a game about cards and points.  You play a card, you gain or lose some points, and the player with the most points when the GAME OVER card is played wins. But there's a catch or two: First, the GAME OVER card is double-sided, so everyone knows where it is at all times.  Second, over half of the cards in WTF contain blanks and you get to fill them in and finish the rules!  You might get a card that lets you determine how many points players gain or lose, or you might get a card that lets you require all players to perform some ridiculous task of your choosing.  Each card simply must follow on the suit of the previous card -- but many of the suits are made up by the players as they play! The big catch is that you actually write on the cards each game, so your deck is always changing.  The result is that the card that seemed funny when it made the player to your left eat his own earwax is a lot less funny when it comes back around to the player on your right!  For even more excitement, you can mix up your deck with another friend's deck and see what happens. Its up to everyone to decide how far you have to go to get points and keep the GAME OVER card out of the point leaders hand.

title: Monsters of the Deep
description: The object of the game is to be the first player to collect three blue monster discs. At each turn, a player spins the spinner and moves his diver down the safety line the number of spaces which was spun. If he lands on an empty space he may move a disc on his safety line to any empty space on his line. Or he may move one of his opponents discs to any empty space along that player's safety line.

title: Bag
types: Party Game Print & Play Word Game
description:
psssst! Hey, buddy. Whats in the BAG?- a creative thinking word game, minus the letters and words, for two or more players

Goal: To form a lattice of interlocking meme (a unit of cultural information that can be transmitted from one mind to another) strings.

You Need:


     A set of BAG tiles. You can download, print, and cut apart our starter BAG tile set . We strongly recommend creating your own set or customizing the starter set. Just glue snippets from magazines onto the backs of the starter set tiles and trim the clipping to fit the tile.
     A bag or other opaque container to put the BAG tiles in.
     A flat surface to play on. 


Each player draws seven tiles from the bag. On your turn, try to find a theme or concept that two or more of them share. One youve found a theme for one or more of your tiles, lay them in the play area. If tiles are already in play, the tiles you play must intersect one or more of them.

Draw one tile for every tile you played. Score one point for every tile in each meme-string you added to or created. Play passes to the left.

The first player with 21 points wins.

title: 'Dillos in Austin
description:
Dillos in Austin: A simulation for 2 to 4 ground-dwelling armored dasypods.

You think road construction is bad in your town? You should try living in Austin. Even without road construction, the signage is confusing and the drivers are absolutely nuts. The only thing that could make navigating the city more challenging is if the roads actually shifted and changed while youre driving.

Object: Get from your home to the capitol building in the middle of town without getting captured by the dillo hunter.

You Need:


     Two 6-sided dice.
     A city map. (provided on the website)
     Road pieces. (provided on the website)
     An opaque bag or other container.
     five pawns of different shapes or colors  one for each dillo and one for the Dillo Hunter. 


On your turn, roll two dice. If you roll doubles, the player to your left moves the Dillo Hunter the amount shown on one die. If a pawn enters a space occupied by a stop sign, it must stop moving. After the Dillo Hunter moves (if it moves), choose one of the dice you rolled. Look up that number on the Action Chart (Twist, Swap, Push, or a combination of these) and take the action indicated by your chosen roll.

If you land on the capitol in the center of the board, you win the game.

title: Shift
description:
A quick card game for three or more players.

Object: Organize the cards in your hand into consecutive matched pairs.

You Need: A deck of cards with four distinct suits (red, yellow, green, blue / hearts, spades, clubs, diamonds / plains, forest, mountain, island)

Give each player two cards from each suit. The rank of the cards does not matter. Sort the cards in your hand so that no card is adjacent to a card of the same suit. On your turn you can shift (move one or two cards from one end of your hand to the other) or swipe (ask any player, 'Do you have any {name a suit}?' If your target has that suit at either end of his or her hand, he or she must give it to you).

If you have four consecutive pairs of suits in your hand at the end of your turn, you win.

title: Fairly Tales
description:
Poison apples, beanstalks, and circumlocution for two or more storytellers.

Object: To guess words chosen by the other players from a fairy tale while keeping yours secret.

You Need: Pencil and paper for each player

Once everyone has pencils, paper, and magic beans, choose a fairy tale for the game. Once a fairy tale has been selected, each player needs to write down five words commonly associated with that tale.

The object of the game is to get the other players to say their secret words by asking questions and through general conversation. Once the game has started, you must not speak your own secret words.

On your turn, pick a person and ask him a question about the story. He has to answer it. Remember, not only is your subject not allowed to use his or her secret words, but you arent allowed to use your secret words either.

At the beginning of your turn, you may instead pass your turn. If all of the players in the game but one pass their turns in one round, then the game ends.

At the end of the game, jot down what you think each players secret words are. Take turns declaring your secret word guesses. Score one point for every correct guess. Score a point for every one of your secret words that no other player guessed. The player with the highest score wins.

title: Tabletop Freeze Tag
description:
A fun way to pass a little time, for two players and some spare change.

Object: The nickel is 'it' and attempts to freeze the pennies by bumping into them. The pennies try to stay away from the nickel and unfreeze any frozen pennies by bumping into them.

You Need:

* 3 pennies.
    * 1 nickel.

Place the nickel and pennies on a table with the nickel in the center and the three pennies surrounding it. Place all pennies face-up. Decide who will play the nickel and who will play the pennies. (You could flip for it.) By flicking the change around the table, the nickel player tries to freeze the pennies, while the penny player tries to keep his pennies in play.

The game ends when all the pennies are frozen and can no longer move. Switch roles and play again.

title: Alien Abduction
types: Deduction Party Game Print & Play Science Fiction
description:
Being abducted by aliens wasnt so bad at first. The transport beam was sparkly and kind of tingly, and their tinny voices sounded like cute little cartoon characters. Then the encounter turned sour You cant remember the rest of the experience clearly, but you still experience flashbacks: Bright lights, glinting scalpels, searing flesh, Barbra Streisand movies, and ruby gouts of blood. Youre never sure what will set them off, but theyre distressing and inconvenient; you can feel yourself getting thin around the edges.

Its time to figure out what the aliens put in your brain, confront it, and get it out of there. Remember, today is the first day of the rest of your life.

Ready? Good. Lets start by getting out of bed

Object: To figure out what your abduction-induced phobias are, have them treated, and regain your sanity.

You Need: Alien abduction requires no paper or props, just dark nights on lonely moonlit roads, and victims.

Alien Abduction is a new spin on Twenty Questions. One player is the Abductee, and the other players are Aliens. If youre an Alien, secretly choose a phobia for the Abductee. The Abductee goes through their 'day', trying to figure out what phobias he now has because of his abduction.

title: Sprawl
description:
A game of strategy, resource management, planning, and diplomacy for three to eight players.

Object: To place as many of your pieces on the board as possible while blocking the other players from doing likewise.

You Need:


     A chess board.
     One set of Looney Pyramids (15 pieces of the same color, five pieces of each size) for each player. 


On your turn, you can Build (Add to an existing tower), Branch (Lay pieces off of a tower or tower branch), or Spore (Start a new tower in a square targeted by a branch point).

When one player has no more valid moves, the game ends at the beginning of that player's next turn. Add up the points in your stash at the end of the game. If you have the least points in your stash at the end of the game, then you win.

Game System

    Looney Pyramids




Design Competitions

    Ice Game Design Competition - Winner in 1st Competition




Online Play


    Super Duper Games

title: Saving Private Checkers
description:
Checkers with an explosive twist for two players. Kinda like a cross between normal checkers and the D-Day invasion....

Object: There are two goals: 1) To get as many of your checkers to the other side of the board and back as possible. 2) To capture as many of your opponent's pieces as possible.

You Need:

* A Poker deck.
    * The checkers from a checkers set.

Play is very much like normal checkers, except that you're trying to get your checkers to the other side of the board and back without either being captured or blown to pieces. (The cards act as 'live squares' -- when you enter a square, you may be blown away.)

http://www.invisible-city.com/play/86/saving-private-checkers

title: Dear World
description: The first player to complete a Secret Mission on Earth and return to the space station wins the game.  To complete the Secret Mission, players use the Knowledge, Co-Operation, and Money points to solve a problem in each of three countries.  Players make up their own solutions, then orbit the Earth to collect the points they need.  They then travel to these countries to deliver their solutions.

title: Masters of the Universe: Battle for Eternia
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Fantasy Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
From the back of the box:

On your way to the Evil lair of Skeletor you'll have to battle with the evil warriors blocking your way. If you're lucky you will even make it past the treacherous Fright Zone trap to confront Skeletor himself. The fate of all Eternia hangs in the balance as you battle Skeletor to Free He-Man.

A basic 3D kids' game with a simple combat mechanic and cute dexterity trap, one of the most interesting features of this game is it allows kids to use their actual Masters of the Universe figures as the playing pieces (the game includes stands to put them in).

title: Crossbows and Catapults: Dragon Battle Set
types: Action / Dexterity Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Miniatures
description:
This game could be combined with the master battle set or used on its own as a standalone game.

The game includes 2 dragons (which are similar to catapults), 2 catapults, 2 crossbows, walls, flags, figures, projectiles, cards, rulers, etc.

The dragons had special firing rules and special 'dragon master' figures that used them.

title: Havok Skirmish Battle Set
description:
The Havok Skirmish Battle Set was a starter set for the short-run miniature war game Havok produced by Bluebird Toys in 1997. As well as this base set additional units  even vehicles were also available in non-random booster packs.

The Havok Miniatures Game was intended to fill a gap in the market by posing as a cheap alternative to Warhammer 40,000. Unfortunately bad marketing and Bluebird Toys' financial shut-down cost the game dearly, and the line (along with the Bluebird Toys company) folded by Christmas 1997.

Initially sold exclusively through Argos stores, all the unit boosters had a single item code meaning customers could not purchase the specific unit boosters they desired (Argos would pick from the boosters 'at random'). At the end of the line remaining Havok boosters were sold in bulk to toy suppliers where they proved surprisingly popular, but it was already too late for the game and many new fans didn't initially realise that the game was already discontinued.

The game itself can be compared to a lighter, more simplistic version of Warhammer 40,000. Two or more players pick forces from three possible factions of the Havok sci-fi universe using a point system, and then battle it out across the tabletop.

In the game's favour the models were made of from durable plastic, pre-painted and simply slotted into their bases which were decorated with simple stickers, meaning there was no modelling or painting required.

The Havok Skirmish Battle Set included everything you needed to play, including a small fixed selection of miniatures, custom dice, range rulers and instructions, as well as four pieces of slot together scenery.

title: Masters of the Universe Snake Mountain Rescue Game
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Electronic Fantasy Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: Very similar to Operation. Players must use a special sword to pick cards out of a plastic 3D Snake Mountain. Hitting the sides of the card holder results in Skeletor popping up and the card being eaten. Requires batteries.

title: Flagge Zeigen
description:
(from the rules)

Contents:
				
					=

96 playing cards
55 money chips
   5 black (worth 50)
   20 green (worth 10)
   5 yellow (worth 5)
   25 red (worth 1)
10 action chips (square)
4 wooden cubes (ships)
Board

Summary:
				
					

Each player gets a ship and tries to fulfill as many freight contracts as possible to have the most money at the end of the game.

This was a promotional game for a German inland shipping company.

title: Heximoes
description: Heximoes includes 132 six-sided cardboard tiles. Each side has a number of dots, between one and six. As in dominoes, you make matches, but must make sure all sides line up: sixes against sixes, fives against fives, etc. In the main game, each player takes six tiles from the box. If you can not make a play, you must draw an additional tile. Play continues until one player has placed all of his tiles on the table, or until no other players can make a play. Variants, including a solitaire, are also included.

title: The War Game
description: Ten great battles of world history are recreated in this unique book, by eight expert military historians. Illustrated with specially commissioned full-color photographs of realistic military miniatures re-enacting each battle, the book is both an impressive and fascinating study of the art of war, and a guide for war-game enthusiasts in setting up their own battle tables.

title: Crossfire Hurricane: The Battle of Long Than – August 1966
description: The 6th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment was composed mainly of conscript soldiers. The Viet Cong D445 Local Force Battalion had dominance in this area but the Australians were increasing their activity. Most contacts with the Viet Cong were small squads and so Australian doctrine was to carry light loads and attack aggressively. The local Viet Cong commander, Colonel Nguyen Than Hong, aimed to make a large attack on 6th Bn causing a politically unacceptable loss, hoping to cause its withdrawal. The Viet Cong 275 Regiment moved south intending to attack. The VC continually formed assault waves and moved forward but were decimated by artillery fire. The soldiers of D Company showed excellent discipline holding their line and repulsing any VC that got through the artillery barrage. D Company were supported by 24 105mm and 155mm guns from Australian, New Zealand artillery units and the US 2/35 Battalion, which fired deeper into VC positions. Over 3,000 rounds of artillery were fired. The Australian A Battery fired rounds every 15 seconds for three hours. The VC were decimated with over 500 killed and 750 wounded. Australian losses were 18 killed and 24 wounded.

title: Hanau 1813
Auerstaedt 1806
Switch & Tip
description:
From the designer:

This is not a game, I just feel terrible every time I get an e-mail telling me someone has bought it, I'm taking it off the net, those of you who have it have a really rare and useless PDF.

the following is ALL LIES!

Played on a 3x3 board with two pieces for each player, Switch and Tip is surprisingly small abstract board game. The two pieces act differently, one moves around the board and the other moves by changing places with other pieces. With two different ways to win there is a surprisingly large amount of depth to such a small game.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module R2 – Reinforcements 1
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

This module adds ships and scenarios for the Federation, Kzinti, Orions, and Andromedans.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module R3 – Reinforcements 2
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

This module adds ships and scenarios for the Klingons, Hydrans, Lyrans, and WYN.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module R4 – Reinforcements 3
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

This module adds ships and scenarios for the Romulans, Gorn, Tholians, and ISC.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module R5 – Battleships
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

This module adds Battleships, Heavy Carriers, and other large vessels for all races, plus scenarios.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module X1 – The  X-Ships
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

From the back of the cover:
The most powerful starships in the galaxy clash in the titanic final battles of the General War.
Module X1 includes a 64-page rulebook with:
- Advanced systems: rapid-pulse phasers, fast-arming heavy weapons, deadly new drones, Stinger X-fighters, faster acceleration, and enough power to use it all.
- 16 new scenarios from the General War through the decisive battle between a Federation X-squadron and the just-finished Andromedan Devastator Battleship!
- 2 X-ship campaigns.
Also includes 96-page book of X-ship SSDs (many entirely new)  108 counters.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module M – Star Fleet Marines
Star Fleet Battles: Module D3 – Booms & Saucers
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

This module adds SSD's and scenarios for Federation, Klingon, and Tholian ships that are able to separate part of the vessel.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Tactics Manual
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description: This was an expansion for the Star Fleet Battles Game System. It was a manual detailing tactics for the game, and included strategy contibutions from many of Star Fleet Battles's top players.  It included advice on energy allocation, weapon use, manuever, and empire (race) specific advice.

title: Ultra Quick Wrestling
description:
From the designer:

Imagine a wrestling game in which you can complete several full fledged wrestling cards in one sitting. Well, imagine no more, thats exactly what youll get with Ultra Quick Wrestling!

With Ultra Quick Pro Wrestling, youll have an entire world of professional wrestling at your fingertips. The game not only resolves winners and losers of matches, but all of theatrical and bizarre story lines of pro wrestling will unfold before your very eyes.

Ultra Quick Wrestling covers all of the bases. The only limit to the possibilities is your own imagination!

title: Cosmic Wow
description:
From the publisher:

A Fantastic War in Space. Take the Galaxy If You Use the Right Power!!

5 Powers at War! Who will be the victor? You have the powers but which of the powers will be right to take another world? Cosmic Wow! is a fast Micro Game of combat on the move as Humans and Alien Powers try to eliminate each other. Cosmic Wow! is a futuristic, multi-player, interactive space fantasy wargame, suitable for two or more gamers of any age.


     A Complete Micro Game 
     Fast  Inexpensive 
     Hours of Fun 
     No Booster Packs 
     No Collectible Cards 
     Brains Not Included 


http://members.aol.com/TRITACGAMES/index.html

title: The Original Superstar Wrestling
description:
'The Original Superstar Wrestling Game was conceived and copyrighted by John Harwood back in the mid 1970s. The game uses wrestlers' repertoires of moves to flow from offense to defense and finally to pin and submission attempts. A pair of dice, the unique wrestler and result cards are all you need to recreate all the action of Pro Wrestling right on your table top!

The game comes with complete rules, cards, game box and dice. It is easy to learn and you can play an 8 match card in less then an hour.

title: Firefly Big Damn Heroes
types: Humor Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
A lighthearted print-and-play chit wargame of gunfighting in the Firefly universe. Includes two boards (a dingy saloon and a desert battlefield), a rulebook, and numerous counters.

From the rulebook:

Welcome to the game about the biggest damn heroes in the Verse! This game is a simple strategy combat game designed for recreating your favorite moments from the show, or to create some of your own 'what-if' scenarios. Try not to take it too seriously, as the designer doesn't really care about logic, physics, reality or the cubic volume of a glass of beer. Rise again and have fun!

title: NFL Playoff
description:
This game was available for all 28 NFL teams around at the time of its publication.  Each team had their own version with that team's helmet on the box, and the playing pieces were mini-helmets of that team and one of their rivals (such as Packers and Bears).  Beyond that, each team version of the game was identical.

The game uses a board very similar to a Monopoly board.  Each team has a square and there are several special squares (Interception, Touchdown, Super Bowl, Kickoff, and Penalty) that each have specific rules as to how they affect the game.

Each turn in the game represents a football play  After the player rolls the dice and moves their helmet, they draw a play card (team space and super bowl space) or penalty card (penalty space) or they score (touchdown space).  There are also special rules for 4th downs, field goals, punts (and returns), kickoffs (and returns), fumbles, and safeties.

The game goes for 4 quarters, each consisting of 25 play cards.  After all of the play cards are exhausted, the game is over, and the player with the most points wins.

title: Monopoly: Green Bay Packers
description:
Basically, Monopoly with Green Bay Packers players (Favre for Park Place), events (Ice Bowl, Super Bowl XXXI), other Packers unique things (cheesheads), and of course, Lambeau Field as Boardwalk for the properties.

Railroads are now downs, chance and community chest are offense and defense now, and Income Tax becomes Lose to Bears.

Prices and card functions are identical to the normal game.

The set comes with six pewter football/Packer themed playing pieces and football shaped dice.

title: Monopoly: 1999 NFL Gridiron
description:
This version of Monopoly plays just like the normal version of Monopoly (with the exception of using a coin toss to determine who goes first).  All of the properties, prices and cards are the same, just named after teams, or football-themed.  Chance and Community Chest are AFC and NFC.  The railroads are replaced by two teams each and the rest of the properties are one team each.  The utilities become TV and Radio.

The two Super Bowl teams from 1999 (Broncos as Boardwalk and Falcons as Park Place) are set as the most expensive, with the rest of the teams just filling out the rest of the properties around the board (including railroads) in the order of their record for the 1998 season.

There are bleachers and stadiums for houses and hotels, and the playing pieces are all football themed, with football shaped dice rounding out the game.

title: Madeline Card Game
description:
From game box: 
It's a travel game! It's a rainy day game! It's a game for the whole family! It's a game you can play alone! The Madeline Card Game is all that and more.

There are three basic matching and memory games to play that will delight children Ages 4 and up. The oversized cards with their cheerful Madeline artwork are easy for beginners to hold.

title: Curious George Take It Away Game
description: The game includes 40 tiles (4 each of 10 scenes from Curious George books). The tiles are spread face-up on the table. One player removes a tile from the table while the other players close their eyes. Then the other players open their eyes and race to determine the missing piece. The first player to identify the missing piece scores a point. This is repeated until someone wins by scoring four points.

title: RealPolitik
description: Political satire themed card game for 4-8 players.  Mechanic is a simple bidding system.  Card trading and screw-thy-neighbor are two major characteristics of play.  Political themes may make the game most accessible to players 15 years and up.

title: Who? What? Where? Jr.
description:
From the publisher:

 Who? What? Where? Jr. is a drawing game for kids. To play, sketch the funny scenes found on your cards. You might get:

 A Bear Riding a Bike in a Cave
 A Cow Jumping Rope on a Train
 A Dog Playing Soccer on the Moon

... thousands of other fun-to-draw combinations. Other players try to guess what you drew for points. The player with the most points after three rounds wins.

Re-implements:

    Who? What? Where?

title: The Invention Game
description: To play, everyone writes down a description of what they think an invention does. Guess which description is real and earn a point. The player with the most points after 5 rounds wins.

title: Indoor Scavenger Hunt for Kids
description: To play, players each take 5 cards and try to find as many things as they can around the house. Players might have to find a a hat, a coin, something that begins with the letter B and many more. The player who completes the most tasks successfully wins.

title: Scavenger Hunt for Kids Board Game
description:
From the publisher:

To play, children turn over 6 cards and race around the house to find all the objects on the cards - such as Something that begins with the letter M, A book with more than 100 pages, A picture of a smiling person and many more.

When time expires, players count up what they've found and move their pawns 1 space for every object retrieved. If a player lands on a Captain Cleanup space then everyone must race to put everything they've found so far back where it belongs. The first player to move his pawn across the finish line wins.

title: It's a Living
description:
From the publisher

You're going to start, and run, a business. You will choose an industry and a business type, acquire the stuff to operate your business, and expand your business as quickly as you can. When it suits your timing, you will want to finish. Along the way get all the Oh Goody and Progress cards you can, and try to avoid getting any Oops cards.

The game is easy to handicap to compensate for differences in skill, age and experience levels and the versions are as varied as you can imagine: a 30 min. game, a role-playing game, an international championship game, and four others.

title: TriXKick
description: A tactical soccer boardgame without luck element. No dice or card deck. Corner kick, free kick, one-two, four chain, penalty, shot at goal and offside: In soccer there is nearly nothing that cannot be replayed with TriXKick. No luck element can compensate tactical failure. Tactics and strategy are the magic words to win this game.

title: Nuke Your Neighbor
description: 2-4 player strategy game played on a large square grid.  Each player appears to have a home area and there are neutral spaces between these.  Cards are somehow involved.

title: Moolah
description:
Moolah is a traditional roll-the-dice move along the track game, wherein the object of the game is to have one million dollars in your bank account.  Interest comes from the risks of keeping cash on hand vs. in the bank, as these are two mostly independent cash sources.  Deposits and withdrawals can only be made at the 'Bank' or a few other squares, so attention must be paid to how much cash one has available.

Re-implemented by:

    Moola Money

title: Lovers Wild
description:
From the introduction to the rules:

Lovers Wild is a fun spoof of sexual morality today. As a player you have been invited to a wild party along with twelve naughty but nice characters. The object of play is for you to score as many seductions as possible.

The board is set up as a modest movie star type estate with various rooms. Bedroom, den, kitchen, etc, with an outside garden, pool, and entrance way. The objective of the game is to move various characters about from room to room, with the intent of gathering as many together in a room as possible. You must have the characters and the room card to score points. So as you move a character towards a room to have a group seduction with other character cards you have in hand, another player may have the same character card, and wishes this character to have a seduction with the players they are gathering in a different part/room of the estate. The more people you can gather in a room together the more points you score. There are optional rules that allow for gay seductions. Like Ticket to ride, the longer the track built the more points, in Lovers Wild the more characters in a room having a seduction, the more points. Multiples of characters must be as equal as possible, if 5 people in a room are having a seduction, 2 or 3 must be women, one woman and four men does not make an seduction or scoring hand. Fast moving game, lay your hand for points if you can, draw a card, move a character. The more players the more difficult larger seductions are. The board in nicely done, and character chits are humorous with a variety of people types, that fits well in with game, with names like Hands a Roaming, Lucy Love Lace, Dolly Pardon. This may be another game lost to the gaming world, where even the author could not put me onto a replacement copy.

title: Lotto: The Fantasy Game
description:
Play commences in the Lotto Shop, players move around the board in a clockwise direction landing on squares that display various game play actions.

The object of each player is to mark off the six numbers selected and circled on their Lotto Entry Coupon.

As each player reaches this point in the game, they move directly to the Lotto Shop, collect $1,000,000, then select and circle another six numbers on a new Lotto Entry Coupon, and wait for their next turn to continue playing Lotto.
the action continues until the first player has won or purchased all six Fantasy Card, Winning Lotto.

Fantasy cards consist of Tropical Islands, Luxury Boat, Shopping Spree, Luxury Mansion, Luxury Car, Overseas Holiday.

title: Knights' Kingdom Challenge Card Game
types: Card Game Children's Game Fantasy Fighting
description: Knights' Kingdom Challenge Card game is based on the LEGO series of Knights' Kingdom.  In the card game, two players face off against each other in a joust with each card bearing the joust symbols (sword, helmet, shield, and Heart of the Magic Shield) and skills (speed, agility, strength and wisdom).  The joust symbols are compared (ala rock-paper-scissors) to determine the challenger and defender.  Then the skill values are compared (the skill chosen by the challenger) to determine the winner of the joust (ala the card game War).

title: Grand Slam
description: The game that lets you hit, walk and score runs by answering questions about big league baseball.  In Grand Slam, you make hits and earn runs like a true baseball fan. Through knowledge of baseball's interesting facts, from World Series to record holders, to All-Star games to Hall-of-Famers, play a nine-inning game against your biggest rival, or form a league and play a season.

title: The Adhesives Family Game
description:
This is a game that was developed to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Henkel group (which manufactures adhesives).

It is a combination of different mechanics.

The aim of the game is to collect a complete set of picture cards. A complete set consists of 8 cards, each with a different colored border. There are also 3 joker cards in the game, which can be used instead of a colored picture card.

The picture cards are placed face up on the board around the movement fields, 4 picture cards are placed face down on special guessing fields.

Each player also has a hand of 3 movement cards, which can be used to move the pawn around the track. When you have played a movement card, the pawn is moved according to the instructions on it (it can be a fixed number or you may have to throw a die).

You can land on different kind of fields, some allow you to take the picture card that is placed next to it. Others allow you to take a guess at the color of one of the face-down picture cards. You can take it if the guess is correct. You can also be allowed to swap picture cards with opponents, you can be forced to give one of your picture cards to another players, you can steal a card from another player or you must play a game of poker to win extra picture cards.

Players with complete sets score 8 points plus 1 extra point per joker. The others score points equal to the longest sequence of cards.

You play 3 games to determine the overall winner.

title: WPTA 21 Fort Wayne
description: WPTA 21 Fort Wayne, Game of Free Enterprise, Money Maker Board Game. The game board is like Monopoly and there are many old time Fort Wayne,IN businesses represented on the board, some are still in existence and some are not. Great nostalgia!

title: Trivia Chase
description:
From the publisher:

Trivia Chase - one of the most exciting board games to be introduced in years!

Comes with 6000 fun and factual trivia questions covering: movies  entertainment, television, music, sports, and general trivia. A role of the die moves your pawn around the board. Where your pawn lands determines the category of your trivia question. You then select a card from the appropriate color category. Each card has 5 questions with different point values (beginner = 10, moderate = 20, semi-pro = 30, pro = 40, and trivia genius = 50).

Includes gameboard, score sheets, 1 die, 12 pawns, 5 game card holders, 6000 question and answer, and instructions printed on the inside box top

title: Let's Play Golf
description:
Let's Play Golf was originated to give both the golfer and non-golfer some of the thrills of golf right in the home, car, plane, or anywhere.

Players draw from different stacks depending how far from the hole they are. Each card tells you how you did and which stack to draw from next or how many putts it took to get the ball in the hole. The winner is who has the least strokes for 18 holes.

Includes 108 plastic-coated cards, score pad, pencil, and instructions.

title: Up To My @*! In Alligators
description:
Components: 5 specially printed dice with alligators on them. A score pad.

Each die has alligators on each side, with values:
  1 (twice)
  2
  3
  4
  @*!

Players take turns to roll all five dice:

no matching gators = add the numbers on each gator
  any pair = 10 plus the points on the other gators
  two pairs = 15 plus the points on the other gators
  three of a kind = 25 points plus the points on the other gators
  four of a kind = 50 points plus the points on the other gator.
  full swamp = 100 points
  five of a kind = 200 points
  five @*! = Automatic Win!

Players may roll (all) the dice as many times as they wish and may stop at any point, scoring for the last roll only. If two or more @*! sides show up the player scores 0 and his turn ends.

First player to 1000 points (suggested) is the winner.

title: Bupkis
description:
Components: 6 regular dice + rulesheet

Scoring: 1's = 100 points, 5's = 50 points
         3 x 1's on one roll = 1000 points
         3 x other = 100 x face value (e.g. 3 x 6's = 600)
         any 3 pairs = 750 points
         a straight (1,2,3,4,5,6) on one roll = 1500 points
         6 of a kind on one roll = Automatic Win

Players take turns to roll the dice. To score the first time, the player must score at least 500 points. Subsequent turns must score at least 350 points.

When a single die or a combination of dice with point value appear, set those aside and add up the point value for those dice. Keep rolling the remaining dice, removing 1 or more dice with point value per roll, adding to your score for that turn, until 350 or more points is scored and the player wishes to stop.

If no points are scored on a roll, the player's got Bupkis (nothing) and scores 0 for that turn.

First player to reach 5000 points wins the game.

title: Mosaik
description:
Abstract boardgame for 2 players. Board must be 11 x 7 squares, with several of the squares divided into 4 smaller squares. Each player has 4 counters which must be placed 1 counters in each of the 4 large squares on the short edge.

Counters most move to an adjacent square, of a different size and color. In large square there can be 4 counters, small squares can only hold one counter at a time.

The player to first move his counters into the opponents start squares wins the game.

This game is found in a Danish book with rhymes, stories and games, originally published in Prague.

title: Kaptajn Flints Skat
description:
Captain Flint's treasure. 16 cards are dealt with 4 to each player.

The player who dealt the cards begins the game by asking any other player for a card. If the player asked has the card he must surrender it. Then the next player takes a turn.

The object of the game is to collect 4 cards which are connected on a red line on the map, and which ends at the Hut or the Tall Tree.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

title: Fodboldspil For To
description:
Soccer game for two.

Played with a special die, showing 1-1-2-2-3-4.

Each player has his own counter, which start in the middle of the board. Read team goes first, rolls the die, and moves as many spaces as shown in any direction. If landing on A or B, you must move one more space. If landing on C you must roll the die again. If landing on D you must move two more spaces.

To score you have to roll the exact amount to land in the goal.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

title: Labyrintspil
description:
Labyrinth game. Each player has 4 counters, one in each of the 4 colors on the board.

All counters start in the middle of the labyrinth.

On a turn a player will roll the die, and move any one of his counters forwards or backwards as many spaces as shown. If the counter stands on a space of the same color as the counter itself, the player gets an extra turn.

First player to get all his counters out wins the game.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

title: Jogo do 25 de Abril: O Mundo das Aventuras do PREC
Iserlohn: Legend of the Galactic Heroes
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
This is a Japanese science fiction wargame based in the anime world of Legend of the Galactic Heroes.

This is a hex wargame on a crucial battle - Iserlohn - in the anime.

Components

    1 rulebook
    1 560x830mm maps
    2 counter sheets (about 460 counters)
    2 character sheets
    2 reference sheets (same contents)
    2 six side dice

title: Le Volpi del Mare
description: Naval warfare simulation in World War I about the attacks of German privateers against the British Royal Navy.

title: Drive By
description:
From the publisher:

Gangs, Vigilantes and Drug Dealers! 
It's a new easy-to-play board game of neighborhood survival as Gangs and Vigilantes try to save their homes from crazed drug dealers. Bullets fly in this exciting and all too real game from Tri Tac.

It's a world of drugs, money, and horror as street gangs use automatic weapons to settle differences. Drive-By is a fast Micro Game of combat on the move as two or more players and vigilantes try to eliminate each other. You can take the neighborhood if you have the guts and guns. Dice not included.

title: The Guess Picture Trivia: Movie Edition
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game Trivia
description: Picture trivia book presents 150 pages of classic Hollywood movies. Answer all the questions to score points and then go a step further and answer the bonus questions to score additional points.  Good interaction party game that can be as short or long as desired.

title: Pocket Pictures
description: A word game where you sketch a phrase or word chosen from five categories (Famous People, Travel, Sports/leisure, Sights  Sounds, and Food/Drink) and others.  Points are awarded to both the sketcher and the player who guessed it correctly.  Good travel game fits in one pocket or purse and can be played in the back of a car while traveling.

title: Imperial Infantry Squad
description:
Imperial Infantry Squad is a tactical-level wargame of combat in the distant future after man has reached the stars. It can best be described as Squad Leader meets Star Wars meets Starship Troopers.

The unit counters represent infantry squads, individual leaders. and support weapons. The support weapons consist of  light, medium, and heavy energy weapons and demolition packs. Infantry types are bit different than your typical grunt. Types include light, heavy, and powered infantry that can fly using rocket packs. There are three forces represented by the counters: Confederation Infantry (the earthlings), Mercenaries (non-Confederation humanoids), and Telzans (lizard like aliens).

The game mechanics are mostly simplified versions of Squad Leader's mechanics with a few alterations as well as the additional nuances required for the futuristic infantry types and aliens.

The game mapsheets are geomorphic to accommodate the various scenarios that are included.

The production quality of the game is not bad, but not up to the better games of the same era (like Squad Leader). Although it's highly (if not shamelessly) derivative, Imperial Infantry Squad a decent tactical-level sci-fi wargame.

title: The Original Lazy Man's Pool
description:
The game board (14 x 22) resembles a pool table (six pockets) and players place pawns on the game board pockets.  By rolling dice that match the pocket, players may draw from the Ball deck and keep the card unless a Scratch card is drawn.  If a Scratch is drawn, players must return a previously won Ball.  When all the Balls are drawn, the round is over and points are scored based on the total value of the ball cards won.  The winner is player with the highest total after five rounds.

Variations included provide rules for 8-Ball, Rotation and 9-Ball.

title: Quazar
description:
Quazar is a large strategic science fantasy wargame - very large, in fact, with 4 27x21 black and white mapsheets (for a total play area of 4.5'x3.5') and 840 counters.

One player takes the human side and defends the entire map against the other, who takes the invading X-Con (aliens, clones, and robots).

The game appears to be a reasonably straightforward wargame of its type, complicated by a fairly wide variety of different unit types and the rules writer, who adopted what I have to assume was a deliberately obtuse style.  For example, the combat phase (with its 8 sub-phases) is called Violent Interaction  Adaptive Reaction.  The space combat results table is called the Space Systematized Probabilistic Outcome.  Etc.

There is a fair amount of chrome, including secret weapons for each side (e.g., the humans can get a planetary defense screen, the aliens can get a space creature which moves around and eats human units).

Contents:
840 counters
4 27x21 mapsheets
2 order of appearance/secret weapon lists
2 guides to opposing forces (guides to your OWN are not included...)
2 priority sheets - one has some rules summaries, the other is just color)
Rules folder
Combat results table sheet
Alien pod chart sheet

title: Operation Husky: The Campaign for Sicily
description:
(from the box:)
    It's June 11, 1943 and the Allies are ashore on Sicily...the race to Messina has begun.  As the Allied player, you have 12 divisions of Americans, Canadians and British.  In all, 467,000 troops commanded by two of the Allies best: General George S. Patton and General Bernard L. Montgomery.  Your objectives are to capture the Axis airfields and supply ports needed for the attack on the Italian boot and the destruction of the German and Italian forces in Sicily - you must not allow their evacuation to mainland Italy where they will live to fight another day.
    As the Axis player, you must methodically withdraw your forces to Messina for evacuation.  Your command consists of the proud, but weary, Hermann Goering Panzer Division and the recently formed, but veteran, 15th Panzer Grenadier Division.  You have 230,000 Italian soldiers to help in your defense, and the Fuhrer has promised reinforcements: the 29th Panzer Grenadier Division and the 1st Parachute Division.
    Now, it's June 11, 1943 and the Hermann Goering tanks are revving their engines for the counter-attack...

Game Features
Impulse Movement
Allied Tactical Air Support
Naval Shore Bombardment
Air Interdiction
Combined Arms Effects
Anti-Tank Capability
Fortifications
Disorganized Units
What if Scenarios

Unit Scale = Battalions/Some Regiments
Time Scale = 3 days/turn
Complexity Level = Medium

Game Components
One 20 x 17 Four-Color Deluxe Mounted Gameboard
390 Oversize Die-cut Playing Pieces
One Rulebook, One 6-sided Die and Several Charts and Tables

title: Rifle-Musket
description: Issue game for Conflict Magazine #7, June 20, 1974.  Special Civil War issue that included a bonus game called The Alamo.

title: Heroscape Expansion Set: Volcarren Wasteland
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Miniatures Science Fiction
description:
Volcarren Wasteland is the second Large Terrain Expansion Set (wave 2.5) in the HeroScape series. It was released as a Toys R' Us exclusive.

There is 1 large booster pack:

     Lava Terrain Pack with Guards

title: Taktika Logical Soccer
description:
A football (soccer) game which emphasizes the tactical aspect of the sport, with just enough luck involved to keep you thrilled.

Short rules summary:
The board is made up of circles resembling positions a footballist can take on the field. The circles are connected by lines which the footballists and the ball may travel along.
Each turn, both player rolls a die, and divides the result between his footballists. For each point a footballist may be moved to an adjacent circle. After that, the ball must be moved the same total amount of spaces. Unlike footballists, it can only change direction if it hits a freindly footballist. The ball's required movement may force the player to give the ball to the opposing team. 
In addition to that, the ball goes to the opposing team anytime a 1 or 6 is rolled.

Has some similarities to Street Soccer, but predates that title by many years.

title: Tivoli-spil
description:
Fun Fair game.

On a player's turn, the player will roll the die and move thr amount on the circular track. Rolling a 6 earns the player 3 notes, and an extra roll. Crossing the start space earns the player 2 notes. Landing on the Target allows the player to roll the die, and on a 1-3 the player earns that many notes, and a 4-6 nothing happens. On the Clover the player draws one of the 7 luck cards. Landing on the Labyrinth makes the player lose one turn.

Landing on one of the rides allows the player to take that ride by playing the corresponding amount of notes.

First player to take all 12 rides wins the game.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

title: I teatret
description:
In the theater.

Each player has 6 rows of 6 chairs. The player rolls two dice, then decides which one is the row and which one is the chair. The player puts a counter on the chosen combination. If the player cannot put a counter on any chair, he looses his turn.

First player to fill a 36 positions wins the game.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

title: Ballonfart
description:
Used playing a dice with 6 colors as shown on the board.

Each player has 3 counters, first player to get all counters to the finish have won the game.

A players turn consist of rolling the dice and moving one of his counters to an adjacent balloon with the same color as rolled. Counters can only move forwards. If the player is not able to use the color rolled, he looses his turn, and the next player takes over.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

title: Blue and Gray
description:
Blue and Gray was granted a patent in 1903, but possibly was not published until Sid Sackson included it in A Gamut of Games

In Blue and Gray, each player begins with 17 guards and one captain set up on the line intersections of a 9  9 grid board. The object of the game is to advance the captain to the center of the board following an outlined path of 17 steps. However, the captain can only advance if the next step along the path is unoccupied by friendly or opposing guards. Guards can move along lines in any direction (except over the central point) and can capture each other by jumping, as in checkers.

title: Math Whiz
description:
Math Whiz is an educational and entertaining math quiz game for ages 12 and up. The game can be played by up to six persons or by up to six teams of two or more persons per team.

You don't have to be a math whiz to win Math Whiz since it is a game of both chance and skill and is designed in such a way so as to allow a player of lesser math skills a chance to win against a math whiz.

The math questions are keyed to the red, blue, green, yellow and brown spaces and the Triple Bonus circle. Players may use pencil and paper to work out solutions to the 1001 math questions. The player or team who first earns three each of the red, blue, green, and yellow chips is the winner and moves the player token into the Math Whiz circle at the center of the playing board.

title: Diner Chess
description:
A game of late-night deduction and coffee for two or more players.

Object: To figure out the secret rules that govern how the other players move pieces on their turn.

You Need:

* An area with diverse items that you can group in general categories. A table with four place settings at your local late-night diner should do nicely.
    * Paper and pencil for each player.

Each player makes up a rule and writes it down. The player's rules dictates how he moves pieces when it's his turn. On each player's turn, the player moves a piece in accordance with his secret rule and then asks a yes/no question to another player. Players can also guess other players' rules for points.

The game ends when all rules but one have been guessed. If your rule remains unguessed, then you lose 1 point. The player with the most points wins.

title: Black Cat
description:
A simultaneous, real time, high speed card game for two to four players.

Object: To build kitty piles consisting of adjacent pairs of cards that add to 10. There are other card sequences that also score points.

You Need: A Poker deck.

You start play with two empty kitty piles in front of you. You may take a card from the deck and put it in one of your your kitty piles. You may only take one card at a time.

The object of the game is to build kitty piles that have specific cards and card sequences in them. It's important to note that you can not rearrange the cards in your kitty pile during play or at the end of the game. That's why you need to pay attention the the cards you grab while you're playing. You're trying to build kitty piles with the following features:

* Card pairs adjacent to each other that add to ten. A pair that adds to 10 is called a Tomcat. (worth three points)
    * Tens. A ten is called a Yowler. (worth one point)
    * One or more face cards of the same type sandwiched between two other cards of the same type. Each face card in a sequence like this is called a Jellical Cat. (worth two points)
    * An unbroken chain of black cards that adds to thirteen. This is called a Black Cat. (worth six points)

The game ends when the deck runs out of cards or (if the game stalls) when someone yells, 'Black cat, black cat, crossin' my path. Don't look back or you'll get scratched!'

The player with the highest point total wins.

title: Dead & Breakfast
description:
Dead  Breakfast - A Spooky Game for 3 - 6 Players

Your Goal: To Scare the Bejeezus Out of Tourists in a Haunted Bed and Breakfast

Published in the October 2000 Issue of Dragon Magazine (#276). The pull-out board depicts a the 6 rooms of a Bed  Breakfast. Every card of a standard 52-card deck is represented by one of the spaces on the board.

Also needed: 8 D6 (including 6 of different colors for the guests of the BB), plus 2 white dice for rolling; a score pad and pencil; about 30 chips in a unique color for each player; a standard deck of cards without jokers.

The 6 colored dice represent the guests, with the number showing representing their level of agitation (each starts at 2, mildly spooked). Each chip represents a ghost that can haunt a room on the board. Different ghosts belong to different players, which is why each player needs their own color of chips.

Play: 
--Draw your hand up to 5 cards.
--Play a card and 'haunt' the room containing the card you played. To haunt a room, place a chip of your color on the top of the stack of chips in that room (unless a chip of your color is on the top of the stack), or begin a stack if none exists. You also haunt adjacent rooms that are already haunted (have chips of any color in the room).
--Move one guest according to the roll of 2 D6

When a guest lands in a haunted room, points are awarded to the ghosts in that room. Points (equal to the guest's spook level - number on the guest's die) are distributed among the ghosts in that room, with more points going to the top ghost.

If a guest stops in a room that is not yet haunted, the player (if any) holding the card for that room can play the card and 'surprise' the guest, scoring points for scaring that guest.

Each time the a guest lands on a numbered room, their rank (number on die) is increased by 1. If the guest is a 6, they 'freak out'. Freaked-out guests are worth negative points.

Play ends when the last card is played. Player with the most points wins.

A few variants are also included in the rules.

title: Operation Overlord: Upgrade Vehicle Supplement
types: Expansion for Base-game Miniatures Wargame World War II
description:
Supplement for Operation Overlord: Normandy 1944 and Expansion giving expanded rules for:
Gun Calibers
Flame Throwers
Smoke launchers
Merged units
Full army lists for German, American and British tank and mechanized infantry.
3 scenarios based on historical battles

Expands:

    Operation Overlord: Normandy 1944 and Expansion

title: Dora the Explorer Play Park Adventure Game
types: Children's Game Educational Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: Dora and her friends are on their way to Play Park and they need YOUR help getting there! Spin the spinner and advance Dora, Boots, Tico or Isa along the path. Who will be the first to get to Play Park? Play until Dora and all her friends make it there! ! Excellent!

title: Symbiote
description:
An organism-swapping card game for three or four players.

Object: To end the game with the most points in symbiotic pairs and royal symbiotes, ideally while hosting the symbiote. Keeping control of the Symbiote makes it easier to gather royal and paired symbiotes.

You Need:

* A poker deck.
    * A double-sided symbiote / parasite marker, like a CD-R from a failed burn.

Players try to make symbiotic pairs (a pair of cards that adds up to 10) or royal symbiotes (a Jack, Queen, and King.) If a player has the symbiote in front of them on his turn, he can draw additional cards. Tens can be used to change the symbiote into a parasite, which will hinder the player who has it.

The game ends when there are no cards in the draw pile at the start of a player's turn. Flip all of your symbiotic pairs and royal symbiotes face-up and add up their values. If you end the game with the symbiote, score an additional point for every symbiotic pair or royal symbiote you have. If you end the game with a parasite, then lose one point for every symbiotic pair or royal symbiote you have.

The player with the highest score wins. Ties go to the player with the symbiote (or without the parasite).

title: Sorcerer's Apprentice
description:
An ever-changing checkers game for two players and an Icehouse set.

Object: To end the game with the most magic hats in your Hat Rack. Gain magic hats by capturing your opponent's pieces. You can put hats on your pieces to grant them special powers.

You Need:

* A checker board (pieces optional)
    * An Icehouse set with red, yellow, green, blue, purple, and clear pieces. If you're not playing with checkers, you'll need two more sets (like opaque white and black) to act as checkers. These rules assume you're using checkers.

Play is just like a normal game of checkers with the following exceptions:

* If you see a capture, you must take the capture. If you have a choice between captures, you must choose one of them to take.
    * When your opponent loses a piece from the board, immediately draw one hat from the Bag of Hats and place it in your Hat Rack.
    * When you lose a piece from the board, you may immediately place one hat from your Hat Rack on any one of your pieces in play that is not currently wearing a hat. This is not mandatory, but optional. Hats confer special powers on the pieces that wear them.

Download Here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/81/sorcerers-apprentice

title: Twelve O'Clock High
description:
Poultron Press Test Series Game #16.

The game covers the bombing of German industrial production by the Americans.  There are Basic, Tournament and Advanced rules. The Americans win by destroying aircraft factories or other industrial targets.  The Germans win by preventing the Americans from attaining their victory conditions.

The board is in black and white on heavy paper.  The rules booklet is 14 page mimeograph.  Counters are good quality.

title: Play It Smart
description: Standard trivia game with a couple of twists.  First, scoring is done on a white board with a marker.  The first to fill their portion of the board black (by answering questions in 6 different categories across 6 different dice rolls, 36 total questions) wins.  Second, the questions are stored in a nice hardcover book, as opposed to your typical box of cards.

title: Glutter of Ravens: Warfare in the Age of Arthur
description:
Rules and resources for wargames in the period AD400-AD700.

The name comes from a line in the Welsh epic Y Gododdin, He glutted black ravens on the walls of the fort, but he was no Arthur.

Daniel Mersey, the designer, is a British archaeologist who wanted a set of miniature wargame rules that specifically captured the style of warfare in Dark Ages Britain in the period between the Roman departure and the coming of the Vikings; the age that was dominated by the legendary war-leader Arthur.

The armies represented in the rules are mostly the British kingdoms that arose after the Romans left Britannia. However, there are also the external enemies of these kingdoms: the Irish, the Picts, and the Saxons. There is also an army list for Romans.

Figures are mounted in multiples on stands that represent warbands. Warband types can be Heavy Cavalry (HC), Light Cavalry (LC), Heavy Infantry (HI), and Light Infantry (LI). The warbands are further distinguished by a set of three characteristics that play an important role in movement and combat. These characteristics are Formation, Aggression, and Strength and are represented by a numerical value that can fluctuate during the game. Based on warband type and nationality or kingdom, there are set maximums for each of these characteristics. If the value for any one characteristic decreases to zero, the warband is lost.

Players control their armies through Command Points that are determined by a die roll. Using his Command Points, a player can move his warbands or increase their Formation and Aggression values up to the maximum allowed. (The Strength characteristic represents the number of warriors in the warband. Once a Strength point is lost, it stays lost.)

Armies are divided into two distinct categories of warband. The Comitatus represents the personal retinue of the leader, the trained warriors whose only job is to be fighters. The Contingent represents levy troops who are not primarily warriors but can be pressed into service to swell the numbers of an army. The maximum Formation and Aggression values for the Comitatus are higher than those for the Contingent.

When choosing the warbands that make up his army, a player must use all the Comitatus warbands in his army list (there are always five). However, he may choose any number of the Contingent warbands from none to all. The number of warbands in the army is a critical pre-game decision a player must make. The starting values for Formation and Aggression are assigned to the warbands from a pool of 30 Command Points that a player starts with. Even if he chooses only the Comitatus, he will likely be unable to start with his warbands at maximum values and must build them up during the game using his Command Points. This building up of the warbands represents the need for a leader to organize and inspire his warriors for them to be at their maximum effectiveness in battle. If a player divides his 30 Command Points between too many warbands, the starting values will be very low and he must spend several turns building up his warbands.

Combat is divided between missile file and melee. Every warband has some kind of missile weapon (javelins, slings, bows). Firing is done by comparing a firing warband's Strength to the target's modified die roll. If the die roll is lower than the firing unit's Strength, some effect is made against the target.

The values that warbands use for melee depends on the nature of contact: warbands that move into combat use their Aggression value, warbands who are stationary when contacted use their Formation value, and warbands that are continuing a melee (no initial contact this turn) use their Strength--the combat has degenerated to a slog bewteen mobs of armed men.
