Blue die = good hitter
Red die = fair hitter
Yellow die = weak hitter
Brown die = scoring for sacrifice or hit-and-run
Green die = stolen base

title: Old Mummy
types: Ancient Card Game Children's Game Educational Memory
description:
(From the website)
WATCH OUT FOR OLD MUMMY!
Learn about ancient Egypt as you play fun card games in the style of Old Maid and Concentration. Collect ancient treasures but don't get caught with the Old Mummy card! The game comes in a keepsake tin box and includes a full-color guide describing the gods, goddesses, symbols and beliefs of the ancient Egyptians.

Discover:

Who swallowed the sun each evening and gave birth to it each morning? 
Why did the ancient Egyptians believe gold was the flesh of the gods? 
What symbol was painted on coffins so the dead could see out onto the land of the living?

47 playing cards and a guide come in a fun tin box in the shape of a sarcophagus.

title: Spellbinding
description:
Spellbinding is a word game where the objective is to successfully identify a scrambled word while in the center space on the board and controlling the dice. The board consists of three concentric circles, divided into spaces, and a large center space.

When a player is in control of the dice, the player to his right is the SPELLBINDER. The SPELLBINDER is the game's arbiter. His duties are as follows: he selects a card from the deck; he scrambles the letters of a word on the card, which is indicated by the board or the second die; he presents that scrambled word; he determines who is the first to correctly identify the word (and whether a tie has taken place). The other players have one minute to identify the word. The first to identify the word gains (or keeps) control of the dice.
If no player correctly identifies the word, play continues to the left.

This process continues until a winner is determined.

title: Enigmako
description: Some criminals are hidden in the city. You're an agent who have mission to establish portraits of theses criminals. After ending this portraits, you compare it to the criminals files at the police station, than you need to catch him and bring him to jail.

title: Hot Money
description:
From the instruction book:

hot money... Will you be a saint or sinner?

The object of the game is to become the first player to reach THE TOP.  To get there you must make millions of $$$, run up hundreds of thousands in debt, and earn a glowing reputation while surviving all the dirty tricks and delaying tactics your opponents play against you.

There are two levels of play:
   The Daily Grind (the outer board) where you must earn your fortune in Cold Cash and/or in Hot Money.
      and
   High Society (the inner board) where you earn your reputation by purchasing the Keys to Success

Hot Money is a roll and move game that uses two currencies, cold cash and hot money.  Hot money comes from various illicit activities, and must be laundered into cold cash before a player can enter High Society

title: Yipes!
description:
A pop-o-matic game where players race to be the first to reach the LABORATORY, become the MONSTER and then chase the other players back to the start, trying to eat them on the way.  The other players try to flee the MONSTER and safely reach the ENTRANCE SPACE.

Points are scored for becoming the MONSTER, reaching the ENTRANCE SPACE without being eaten and for being eaten (for good taste!).  The player with the most points after 3 rounds is the winner.

title: Chikara
description:
Chikara is a strategy game for two players.  Each player has 26 sticks of one colour and plays from behind a black defensive line towards the opponent's line.  The winner is the player who can first place a stick horizontally on the opponent's defensive line, with that winning stick being untouched by any opposing stick.

Sticks are removed when they touch an opponent's playing piece.  Extra moves can be achieve through the use of reserve sticks held within strongholds.  Attack is the best form of defense.

title: Word Spin Scramble
description:
Each player or team has a number of magnetic wheels with letters on them. Players rotate, exchange, or trade their letter-wheels in an attempt to form the greatest number of high-scoring words. The game also includes rules for solitaire play.

1995 Mensa Select

title: Alagar XVI
description: A checkers type game, using the standard chess type board.  Pieces range with values 1 - 4, and the goal is to capture opponents pieces to total exactly 16 points.  Pieces only move the value on the piece in straight lines, and capture by landing directly on the opponents piece.

title: Quipto
description: Game is a rummy type word card game. At the beginning of your turn, draw a card from the discard pile or top of deck.  If you draw more than 1 from the discard pile, the last/bottom card must be played/melded in a word.  With your hand of cards, you can create words or steal words from other players by adding onto the beginning or ending of their word.

title: Corner the Market: Buy and Sell – With Play Money
mechanisms: Roll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description: Move around the board by the throw of the dice. Follow instructions on the board. If you enter Commodity Pit, you buy and sell contracts in order to get a corner on the market. If you land on a Buy square in the Pit you must buy at least one contract of that commodity. If you stop on a Sell square you must sell at least one contract of that commodity. If you land on a Swap square you must trade at least one contract with the player on your left. If you land on open trading you must buy, sell or trade one contract. If you do not complete the transaction then you must pay a fine.  Game lasts a year of seasons, the player with the most assets wins.

title: Turn the Tables Checkers
description:
Checkers with a new twist!

The board is a hex composed of knobs with five knobs per side.  There are four disks embedded in the play field with seven knobs on them, and the disks rotate.  Each player has 12 checkers that fit over the knobs.  Players move forward (only) and capture on hex diagonals like checkers.  If a player has a checker on a turntable, they may turn it as far as they like in lieu of moving a checker.

You win by capturing all your opponent's pieces, just like...you guessed it...checkers.

title: Tournament Golf
description:
It's Just Like Golf...Without the Walking

The double-sided board is an overhead view of all 18 holes of the Green Valley Country Club (6760 yards, par 71), with greens, traps, rough, woods, and hazards.  The board is also ruled off in squares, with each square 20 yards per side on the scale of the holes.

There are 14 dice representing four woods, eight irons, a wedge and a putter.  These have various ranges (in yards)appropriate for the club printed on the faces.  Another die called the directional die has either hook or slice and a yardage on each side.

Players hit their ball (represented by a colored tee) by announcing the direction they're hitting - one of the eight cardinal points - and rolling the directional die and the die for the club they're using.  The new ball positioned using the die values and the grid.  There are various rules restricting club use depending on the type of landscape you're hiting from.  Once you're on the green there's no direction to worry about, just range and the odds on putter die.
 The manufacturing quality of the game is very good, almost extravagant.  The box is hefty, there's a nice cork-lined plastic holder for the dice, a pad of score cards, and large cards printed with golf terms, club ranges, and even golf etiquette (Replace divots.).

title: Touristo
description:
Touristo
The Board Game of Singapore

From the rules:
TOURISTO is a board game for two or more players. The play consists of getting to know some of the interesting places in Singapore, collecting as many token points as possible and escaping the multifarious pitfalls that are intricately simulated in the pot luck cards. Each player competes for the highest token value and he can strategize and take advantage by using his discretion wisely. The players can also have great fun and laughter with the creative catch-phrases that are used to portray the interesting places.

This game was obviously targeted at the tourist market. It is small, portable and features tourist destinations in Singapore, some of which are no longer around. References to the defunct Van Kleef Aquarium and Bukit Turf Club date the game to the 1980s or early 1990s.

It features a Monopoly style board with pictures of the tourist attractions on the spaces. There are 'Pot Luck' cards that act like chance cards, and token cards with point values that the players are trying to collect. Player's pieces feature a tiny Merlion's head.

title: Touristen-Nepp
description:
Touristen-Nepp (The word means taking 'easy' money from tourists) let 3-8 plays have the 'holiday of their life'.
On a map you have to buy the right equipment to have a good holiday, boots for nature, sunglasses for the beach and 'something to be saved' for the sexual experience. And all is in the game as material, small plastic cars, small boots, small sunglasses and also, umm!!, the 'other things' ;-).

title: Cranium New York Booster Pack
types: Expansion for Base-game Party Game Trivia Word Game
description:
Cranium New York Booster Pack is a 45-card expansion to Cranium. It was created to raise money for the September 11th Fund. All cards pertain to New York City in some way, requiring players to impersonate famous New Yorkers, remember New York history, and draw and sculpt New York landmarks. The set contains 12 Star Performer cards and 11 cards each in the Creative Cat, Data Head, and Word Worm categories.

Expands:

    Cranium

title: Pit-Witz
description:
Pit-Witz is an abstract strategy game system made in Singapore. The rules that come with the set describe 9 games that may be played with the set.

In the basic game of Pit-Witz, each player has 8 pieces and tries to get them from his corner to the opposite corner. The board is like a cross-word grid and pieces move like chess rooks. In making a move, the pieces have to move all the way down a corridor, until they encounter a dark square or another piece. Other games add the use of dice and money (called witzers).

The names of the other games are:
Jet-Witz
Banditz
Dice-Witz
Plus-Witz
Haggle-Witz
Stomp-Witz (also known as Beetles)
Claim-Witz
Morlocks

title: Maze
description:
Maze - A Maze Building Strategy Game For Two

The object of Maze is to construct a maze with as few tiles as possible, and to move your pawn through it from Start to Finish.

Each player starts with their Start/Finish tile on the table. Each turn, the player rolls a pair of dice. That player will then choose 2 out of the 3 options to perform, and allocates one of the rolled dice to each of those options. The options are:

Option 1: The player turns tile face up from a face down stack, until the number of face up tiles matches the number on the chosen die.

Option 2: The player chooses the number of tiles indicated by the die, and adds those tiles to their existing maze.

Option 3: The player advances their pawn through their maze as many squares (there are 2 squares per tile) as the die indicates.

The tiles have various configurations of bold lines around certain edges, indicating walls of the maze. When the maze is completed, it must be fully enclosed by the border, and all squares must be reachable by the pawn.

The round ends when a player has completed their maze and has moved the pawn from the Start to the Finish, entering Finish with an exact die roll. Alternatively, a round can end when both players have run out of tiles, and one of them has reached the end of their incomplete maze. Scores are tallied using various factors (number of squares in the maze, number of squares needed to complete the maze, number of squares the pawn needs to travel to reach the Finish, number of squares on unused face up tiles), and low score wins the round.

Rules are also included for variants to adjust the difficulty of the game.

(C) The Game Works, Inc.  1983

title: Crossword Challenge
description:
From the box:
Crossword Challenge gives you all the fun of a regular crossword as well as the chance to compete with your friends or family. Each player or team has a pad of blank crosswords. The Cluemaster reads a clue and the first person to grab the Gizmo has the opportunity to answer.
The result is a hilarious grab for the Gizmo to make sure you answer first and get the points. 
There are 40 puzzles in the book with varying degrees of difficulty.

Contents include: game board, gizmo (small soft plastic toy), 1 clue book, 5 crossword playing pads, 5 pawns, 5 pencils.

title: Jumping to Conclusions
description:
Object of the game: Place the cards face down and the counters in the center of the players. It is useful to play the game in sessions, by breaking the pack into two or three roughly equal parts. Keep the bottom card last.
The first player reads the clues on the first card to the other players, starting with the points at the top. The other players may try to answer at any time, without awaiting turns, but each player is allowed only one answer per clue. Where two or more players give the same answer together only the first is counted. Players may pass instead of answering that clue. 
a correct answer wins the points indicated for that clue. Players pick up counters for their points. An incorrect answer loses five points. 
Players take turns round to read the clues. Highest score after the last card is the winner.

title: Tengamo
description:
Tengamo offers four different games that can be played in this collectible magnet game. Game packs come with 6 random characters magnets (of 60 current) and a steel marble.

In Roller Ball, each player tosses the same number of pieces onto the playing surface.  Players then take turns rolling their steel balls to collect opponents until all pieces have been captured.  Pieces have different point values, and the player with the most points wins.

In Magnetic Pull, one game piece is placed in the center of the playing surface, and each player uses the magnetic properties of another Tengamo piece to try to drag the center piece to their side of the table.  Pieces are placed in the game by both players until all have been used and collected.  The one who has attracted the most pieces to their side wins.

Stack and Build allows players to create different shapes and images with pieces.

Fridge Throw can be played one of two ways.  Players can throw Tengamo pieces on metal objects, such as the refrigerator, and try to connect without touching their opponents' pieces, or they can throw their pieces at the object and try to hit their opponents' pieces.

title: Check Lines
description: A two player game using an asymmetric board.  Each player has five pieces and to win must be the first to position these so that they have two straight lines, both of three men (i.e. one piece must be used in both lines)

title: Capital Talouspeli
mechanisms: Commodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:
Capital Talouspeli (economy game) is a Finnish Monopoly-like economy game manufactured by Nelostuote Oy.

From the box (translated from Finnish):
Make business in stock markets or gamble with savings and interests.
As a real estate agent you buy and build estates and make money with them. As an investor you buy stocks, gain power for general meetings, or maybe you just do some cornering.
To win the game you must have right profile, strategy and tactics, but luck is involved in both good and bad. There are limitless number of player roles. You can thrive in many ways, as in real life.
When necessary, you have to change your chosen tactics and strategy. Inherited assets and lottery prizes can make surprising changes in the game. Wealthy players may buy their very own jet plane and fly around the world from business to business. Illegal businesses may sound nice, but risks are great.
Your game doesn't end in bankruptcy! After the debt restructuring it's still possible for you to win the game. The game may even be used to educate company management.
Have fun while developing your strategical, tactical and psychological skills.

title: Tai Chi
description:
In Tai Chi, each player has a Yin and a Yang token, which they attempt to guide to meet at the center of their score track by playing numeric cards that move the token one direction or the other.

Cards are played face down, and three from your hand of five are be played to move either of your own two tokens or your opponent's before revealing and resolving scores.

If a token lands at the center point, it may only be dislodged by a pair of identical cards being played on it.

Did your opponent just place a card on your track to move you away, or did he play a zero to bluff you into counteraction?

title: Winner's Circle
description:
Each player is dealt a Program card that specifies a colored horse pawn and the betting odds for that horse.  Each player is also dealt four movement cards.  Based on the strength of those movement cards, each player places bets on his horse. Bets can be to Win, Place or Show on a player's own horse. The players have the option to place a Daily Double bet, which in this game is betting that the player's own horse will win the first two races. The players, one at a time, play a movement card.  Most of the movement cards specify a number of spaces to move the player's horse pawn. Some of the movement cards state, Ask Jockey.  Ask Jockey means that the player turns over the top card of the Ask Jockey deck.  The Ask Jockey cards are marked on their backs with a blue dot if the card has advantages for the player, red dot for disadvantages for the player, question marks ?? for instructions that may or may not affect the player that plays it.  Holding an Ask Jockey card until that deck has a card with a blue dot on top is ideal. After the players have put into play and discarded all of the cards dealt, the entire movement deck is shuffled and four more cards are dealt to each player. Ask Jockey cards can require a player to give a number of his movement cards to another player or just discard them without using them.  Therefore, players may use more or less than four movement cards per hand dealt. After the second race is complete, the Program cards are shuffled and dealt for each race.  The race track board is proportionally marked for all of the common lengths of horse races.  A game is complete after an agreed upon number of races and the instructions recommend 8 races.  The most money wins.

This is NOT Knizia's Winner's Circle

title: Egypt to Canaan No.1 The Plagues of Egypt
description:
This is the first in a series of 4 games in the Egypt to Canaan Hebron series of bible games published by Good Reading Limited in the 1970s.

Like the other games in the series it is a roll-and-move game and uses a D8 which it calls a 'Pyragon'.

From the rules:
These exciting games have been carefully planned so as to give a constructive idea of the history of Israel from Bible, from the time of the captivity in Egypt up till the time of the settlement in the land God had promised them.

title: Egypt to Canaan No.2 The Wilderness Wandering
description:
This is the second in a series of 4 games in the Egypt to Canaan Hebron series of bible games published by Good Reading Limited.

Like the other games in the series it is a roll-and-move game and uses a D8 which it calls a 'Pyragon'.

Players try to get their Cloud and Israel markers to Sinai.

From the rules:
These exciting games have been carefully planned so as to give a constructive idea of the history of Israel from Bible, from the time of the captivity in Egypt up till the time of the settlement in the land God had promised them.

title: Egypt to Canaan No.4 The Conquest of Canaan
description:
This is the fourth in a series of 4 games in the Egypt to Canaan Hebron series of bible games published by Good Reading Limited.

Like the other games in the series it is a roll-and-move game and uses a D8 which it calls a 'Pyragon'.

Players race to encircle Jericho seven times to conquer it, capture Ai, capture five kings and move round twelve tribes.

From the rules:
These exciting games have been carefully planned so as to give a constructive idea of the history of Israel from Bible, from the time of the captivity in Egypt up till the time of the settlement in the land God had promised them.

title: Stoner Trivia, A Card Game
description:
Well, it's finally here, a game devoted to marijuana trivia. Answer questions about Stoner movies, Music, History, Paraphernalia, Law, Medicine, Sports, Television, Unjust Bust, World culture, Horticulture, and more. These questions will leave you and your friends chatting for hours!

Stoner Trivia is a fun, novelty card game that tests your knowledge about marijuana and the stoner culture.

Each Stoner Trivia Card has a point value of +2, +3, +5, or 10 points which determines the difficulty of the question. Answer questions correctly to build up points to trade in for DOOBIE Cards. Collect 4-20 point DOOBIE Cards and win the game!

This game includes 350 Stoner Trivia questions, 25 DOOBIE Cards, 20 BUZZ Cards, 10 BUSTED Cards, 15 HAPPY TOKING Cards and a set of game direction

title: Paddington
types: Card Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
This children's card game contains 36 cards (9 different sets of 4 cards) depicting Paddington Bear from the BBC's 1970's children's TV series.

Cards are shuffled and dealt 5 to a player. The remaining cards form the draw pile, and the top card is turned over to start the discard pile.

On a player's turn, he may take the top card from either the draw pile or the discard pile. He then discards a card.

Each player aims to collect two sets - one of 3 cards and a pair. When a player completes a set during his turn, he places it face up on the table in front of him. The first player to lay both sets on the table is the winner.

title: Period Pieces
description:
This card game was published for the (British) National Trust by Dinosaur Publications.

The game comprises a set of 48 cards, 44 of which depict different furnishings from the Jacobean, Georgian, Victorian and Modern periods. The other 4 are 'House' cards, and they are used as Jokers which can be substituted for any other card.

The object of the game is to collect two sets of 3 or 4 object cards of the same period (e.g. Jacobean) or 3 or 4 object cards of the same type (e.g. lighting). The sets are:

1. Kettles
2. Tables
3. Clocks
4. Chairs
5. Toys
6. Cradles
7. Cabinets
8. Lighting
9. Musical Instruments
10. Irons
11. Vessels

PLAY
Seven cards are dealt to each player, the rest are turned face down to form the draw pile, with the top card being turned face up to start the discard pile. Each player in turn draws the top card from either the draw pile or the discard pile. He then discards a card. As a player collects a set of 3 cards he may, if he wishes, place them face upwards on the table in front of him and score their total. Any player having the fourth card to the set may, in turn, place it in front of himself and score its number. The game ends when one player has disposed of all the cards in his hand.

SCORING
Cards score according to the numbers on them. House cards score 20. All cards still in the hand of a player score against him, and all cards on the table score for the player who has collected them. The first player to score 200 points is the winner.

title: Batter Up Baseball Card Game
description:
Batter Up is a Baseball card game (using the rules of baseball) consisting of 36 cards and a fold out paper field depicting the Baseball diamond. The cards are:

BALL (x11) 
FLY OUT (x2)
STRIKE (x10)
FOUL BALL (x2)
STOLEN BASE (x1) 
OUT (x3)
SINGLE (x3)
DOUBLE (x2)
TRIPLE (x1)
HOME RUN (x1)

The first player at bat shuffles the cards, turning over 1 card at a time, until he gets a hit or an out. If he gets a hit, he places the card on the indicated base. The play is carried on as in an actual baseball game. When 3 outs are made, the playing side is retired. The opposing team comes to bat and the cards are reshuffled.

Special rules can be made. For example, it is optional to advance all base runners one extra base on a single and a double. This game may also be played as a party game where players take positions on bases.

A record of the balls, strikes and outs may be kept by a member of the opposing team calling out each card as it is turned over.

title: Metal Mental Meltdown
description:
The world's first heavy metal trivia board game.

Metal Mental Meltdown features questions that cover ALL genres of metal, from the NWOBHM to the gutters of the L.A. Glam scene to the snowy shores of the Scandinavian Black Metal invasion.  There are thousands of questions about hundreds of bands and performers from the 70's, 80's and 90's.  The questions are divided into four challenging categories: Head Bangers (fairly easy), Cranium Crackers (medium), Skull Krushers (hard) and Mental Meltdown (insanely hard!).

title: Profit
description: Basically a Roll and Move game about - you might have guessed - making the most profit. Buy and sell goods, upgrade your ship to an airplane, build warehouses etc. Game ends when one player runs out of money.

title: Death Test 2
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Wargame
description:
Death Test 2 was MicroQuest #2 in the Metagaming MicroQuests series, programmed adventures for Melee and Wizard.

Sequel to Death Test, this paragraph-based adventure for the Melee/Wizard fantasy combat system recreates its predecessor's dungeon-crawl scenario but is significantly more difficult.

title: Fear Factor Game
description:
First saw this game at Universal Studios Florida and have now seen it showing up around the net stores.

You roll the dice to match the correct color combination on the stunt card faster than your opponent. Smash the spider (making it squeak) to win that round and move ahead! The first to make it from the Start space to the $50,000 winner space wins the game!

Cards have images taken directly from the TV show. Stunts are NOT performed, just read from cards. Game includes plastic bug shaped pieces and a black vinyl squeaking spider.

title: Oraïa
description:
The game is based in the 4 elements: water, air, earth and fire. 
Each player choose one color and put his tokens in the starting places. Each player make alternate moves with his tokens.
The winner is the player who manage to move his tokens to the opponent's starting places.

Home Page: http://www.oraia.com/

title: Crossfire Bingo
description:
Crossfire Bingo - alternative to Bingo but make your own luck. 
Each player has there own crossfire board and about 25 counters for covering the spaces. 
Players take turns to roll the dice and cover a space or spaces on the board according to the numbers showing.
Example a a three and a five are showing
Options 1 cover the space 8 (by adding the dice together
2) Cover 3 and 5
3) Cover space 35
4) Cover space 53
To win the game you must have two rows of seven numbered spaces covered (D spaces included) with one row running vertically and the other row horizontally.

title: PersonaliTease
description:
From the back of the box:

This is a party game... not a board game.

You don't have to sit around a table in uncomfortable chairs so you can just sit back and relax.

You never have to answer uncomfortable questions so you won't end up in divorce court.

You don't have to know tons of trivia or how to spell or how to draw or how to act or how to do anything.

You never have to roll dice, move markers, count change, or jam annoying little plastic pieces together.

You simply need to hang out and have fun.

Want to show your friends how well you know them? Take out the PersonaliTease party game and have everyone guessing who answered questions like What do you enjoy doing, even though you know it's wrong? One playerthe emceecollects personality answers from the group, reads them out loud once or twice, and waits for everyone to guess which answer belongs to which player. There's plenty of bluffing and second-guessing involved here, and (fortunately) little opportunity for hard feelings to develop, as can sometime be the case with other games of this kind. The game can go as quickly as you like, or linger for a long evening of discovery if you want to really explore the mysteries of your friends' minds. What kind of vegetable does the person on your left remind you of? Wild personalities questions... with even wilder answers!

title: Hot Wheels Acceleracers Collectable Card Game
description: Hot Wheels Acceleracers is a collectible card game based on the popular Mattel toy. Players race their cars across four realms, trying to be the first player to get three cars to the finish line. Spend Action Points to play Mod cards to permanently boost your car, or Shift cards to give you a temporary boost. If your car meets or exceeds the target number for the realm, then you speed on to the next one. Watch out, though, because your opponent can play hazard cards to try to destroy your Mods, or even your car!

title: Therapy: V.I.P. Edition
description: In this new edition of Therapy, players move through the six stages of life answering questions. Special cards covering the quirks of (in)famous persons have been added.

title: Culture & Conquest
description:
CULTURE  CONQUEST
Simulation of ancient civilizations. 
This dice game does not require a map or counters.
Solo or any number can play.
Published in Academic Gaming Review
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Culture.html

title: Pooh Musical Hide 'n' Seek Game
types: Children's Game Educational Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme Novel-based
description:
Press Pooh's head to play the music and make his friends peek out from their honey pots.  Who's hiding in which pot?

To play, flip over a card and try to find the matching character.  To win, match all 6 of your cards by finding all 6 of Pooh's friends: Piglet, Tigger, Eeyore, Rabbit, Owl and Kanga!

title: Epic Battles Trading Card Game
types: Card Game Collectible Components Fighting Video Game Theme
description:
From the publisher:

Score Entertainments premier set of the Epic Battles TCG features characters and game situations from both Midway Amusement Inc. and its Mortal Kombat Deception video game and Capcom and its Street Fighter III: Third Strike video game. Street Fighter and Mortal Kombat starter decks and booster packs will be sold separately, but both utilize the fully compatible Epic Battles TCG fighting mechanic. Fans can finally position Ryu against Liu Kang, Blanka against Baraka, or M. Bison against Sub Zero in the same arena of play.

Epic Battles TCG can be found exclusively in September at Blockbuster stores nationwide.

title: Fantastic Mr Fox
description:
Based on the book by Roald Dahl, players take the role of Mr. Fox, racing towards the feast at the end of the track but avoiding the farmers Boggis, Bunce and Bean.

Microbadges:
 Fantastic Mr. Fox Fan

title: Diceland: Penny Arcade
types: Action / Dexterity Collectible Components Comic Book / Strip Dice Expansion for Base-game Fighting
description:
Single die Diceland expansion released as a Summer 2005 promo. Features Penny Arcade characters.

All Diceland sets are 25 dice. Ogre was 17 dice, but Space used the rest of the sheet with 8 dice. Cyburg and Dragons were both 12 dice, leaving Cheapass with one space left. So they slapped some Penny Arcade graphics on it (yes, from the webcomic) and you have a special die.

Interestingly, though, it's not just another die. It introduces a few new concepts. One is Hammer, which hits a target die multiple times. Another interesting aspect is that it's actually two dice! You see, in Diceland, most dice get damaged one side at a time, from side 8 to side 1. The Penny Arcade die, however, has two side 4s, side 3s, 2, and 1 - essentially, it's like two 4-sided Diceland dice stuck together. There are also ways to shift from one 'track' to another, changing the abilities of the die. Interesting.

List of Diceland sets and armies

title: Click
description:
Described on the box as a gripping new dice game this is Waddingtons take on Yahtzee.  The object of the game is to secure the highest score with eleven turns of rolling five dice.

Players first try for six combinations (straight, full, high, etc.).  If they fail to score a combination they will add up the matching numbers and enter the most advantageous of them in the left hand numbers column on one of the scorecards.  Players may re-roll the dice three times on their turn.  On each throw the dice needed are put aside.

Combinations are only scored once each.  If you fail to get a combination but have already filled in the number boxes then a zero must be entered in one of the score boxes.  The Click of the title is a combination of all five numbers the same.

title: Monty Plays Scrabble
description:
A portable electronic device that plays a competent game of Scrabble. Up to three players may challenge the device. Each player enters one's own name and subsequently the turn order in which they will play. The players can decide to draw their own tiles or let the device do the randomizing. If the device assigns the tiles, the players may ask the device to suggest a play by using the Hint option.

Players keep track of the gameboard using the paper pad provided or use their own gameboard. The device has a LCD readout that is only eight characters by four characters and cannot display the entire board. Players use the arrow keys of the membrane keyboard to scroll around.

All standard Scrabble rules apply. The device will challenge any word played that is not in its 12,000 word (politically correct) vocabulary. The human player is final arbiter however.

The device is powered by four C batteries or an AC adapter. Two Advanced Vocabulary Modules were available. Each module added 16,000 words to the machine's vocabulary to bring the total to 44,000.

title: The Invasion of Sicily
description:
This fine game was published in 1972 in Panzerfaust magazine, with an unmounted map in four sections, unstapled rulebook in two sheets, and unmounted two-sided counters -- one of the very first (if not the first) wargames to use two-sided counters for step reduction. Fortunately, a mounted die-cut set of counters was available for like $1 additional, so we were spared the nightmare of trying to hand-mount two-sided counters shudder.

The Mapsheet consists of four sections (mine are hand-glued into one map) showing the island of Sicily, in light and dark blue and light and dark brown on white paper, 19 x 27 assembled. The Combat Results table (from 1-4 to 7-1), Terrain Effects chart (six types), Time Record track (12 four-day turns), Unit Designations Within Divisions chart (initial Axis), German Order Of Battle chart (reinforcements and What If? units), and Allied Order of Battle chart (initial and reinforcements) are all printed on the mapsheet. The starting Axis locations for the historical scenario are printed on the map, as are the historical and alternate Allied landing sites.

The Rulebook assembles into 8 pages. Front is picture, title and credits. Second page is historical info (Introduction). The next four pages are rules and victory conditions. Then 1/2-page of (six) alternate scenarios, 1/2 page of designer's notes, and 1/2-page of bibliography (on the last page, with instructions for assembling the mapsheet).

Units are mostly regiments and brigades (or similarly-sized kampfgruppen), with some battalions, some Italian divisions, and an Army HQ for each army (4). There are 120 of the 1/2 counters -- 22 Americans (olive green, 3 are battalions, 1 is Army HQ), 18 British and Canadians (dark olive green, 1 is Army HQ), 39 Italians (yellow, 3 are divisions, 11 are battalions, 1 is Army HQ), 25 Germans (tan, 1 battalion, 1 Army HQ), and 16 blanks, some of each color. The mounted counters are unique in that the full-strength side is printed on what is normally considered the back of the counter. While it doesn't look as nice, it does actually facilitate handling the counters - they are easier to pick up. Another idea that never caught on.

This is not a complex game, more along the lines of the old Conflict games. The game sequence is 1. Allied airdrops; 2. Allies move; 3. Allied combat and post-combat moves; 4. Axis airdrops; 5. Axis moves; 6. Axis combat and post-combat moves. ZOCs are fluid for movement and rigid for combat. Combat is odds-based, with step losses, retreats and advances indicated for both attacker and defender. For example, at 1-1 odds, the results are: 1. Att 1 step retr 1, Def adv 1; 2. Att 2 steps retr 2, Def adv 1; 3. Att 1 step, Def 1 step retr 1; 4. no effect; 5. Def retr 1; 6. Def 1 step, retr 2. Stacking is 3 regt/brig. Rules for invasions, airdrops, supply, evacuations, and naval support fire are all simple and non-cluttered.

One interesting aspect is Italian desertion. On turn one, the Axis player must roll for every Italian non-infantry unit, losing it to desertion on a 3-6 on 1D6. The Italian infantry are sturdier, and will not desert unless attacked at 3-1 or more with no German unit within three hexes.

Victory conditions are based on three elements: Italian desertion, casualties, and cities held. Levels of victory are: Axis wins if he has more than 3/4 of Allied points, decisively if equal or more; game is drawn if Axis has less than 3/4 but at least 2/3 of Allies points; otherwise Allies win. Also, the Axis win immediately if they destroy both the US 7th Army and UK 8th Army HQs (not bloody likely).

I can't believe no one ever listed this game before. It is one of my all-time favorites.

title: Gefangen in der Geisterbahn
types: Horror Movies / TV / Radio theme Novel-based
description:
Directly translated Trapped in the ghost train

A new horror-themed game from the author of Return of the Heroes.  Players have to find three keys, in order to leave the ghost train again, before their morale bottoms out, because they have to face various creatures from classic horror stories and films.

title: Kobe Mini-Yard
description:
A table game with a circular board that has four pockets. The board is made of wood and has a circumference of 85 cm. It revolves like a lazy Susan so players need not stand up. The games have elements of Carrom and Billiards (The name is a contraction of 'mini-billiards').
Each player has a hand held spring-loaded cue with which they try to hit various colored wooden pucks into the pockets.
There are at least three different games that can be played. For example, Direct Pocket, where points are scored for knocking the pucks into the pockets (eg a red puck is worth 5 points, a green is worth one point). There is Battle Game, where you try to pocket your opponents' pucks by striking them with your own.
There is also a game set called Octo Mini-yard which has an octagonal board.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module Y1 – The Early Years
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

From the back of the cover:

The Wars that Shaped a Galaxy...
come alive in Early Years, when alliances (and even Star Fleet) were yet to form.
- Complete history of the Early Years, with maps showing changing borders.
- The Early Starships: More than 50 Early Years cruisers, tugs, destroyers, dreadnoughts, and frigates; the first ships built from scratch to use warp power.
- The Early Bases: 20 SSDs showing the outposts that established ten empires and the stardocks that build the first starships.
- Warp-converted Ironclads: 20 ships that made the conversion from sub-light engines and lasers to warp power and phasers.
- The Federation National Fleets: Rigellian, Andorian, Alpha-Centauran, Vulcan, and even Orion ships of the National Guards!
- Two new races: The Paravians (warrior birds descended from Gorns) and the Carnivons (vicious canines at war with the Kzintis and Lyrans) are introduced.
- Five new scenarios display the wars that began all wars.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module S1 – Scenario Book #1
Star Fleet Battles: Module S2 – Scenario Book #2
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

From the back of the cover:

Ten General Scenarios: Rebel Reduction, Race to the Base, Graveyard of Ships, Black Hole Mania, and five more. Plus the solitaire adventure Maw of Charybdis.

Thirty-seven Historical Scenarios: Internal Disorder, Tug of War, Rescue the Supply Tug, First Sing of the Hornets, Pirate Stew, Tricked!, Faulty Logic, Desperate Days, A Double Surprise, Long Shot, Center of Attention, Tortoise and the Hares, Operation Achilles, Circle the Echelon, The Last Fling, and nineteen more! Plus, the three-scenario mini-campaign Kroal's Illegitimate War!

Three Monster Scenarios: Ice Monster, Metamorph, and the space dragon Mating Frenzy!

Two new campaigns: LDR Commander (three new scenarios), and Survey Cruiser Captain!

Special Bonuses: Asteroid Field Map in stunning full color! Prime Teams in SFB!

title: Box Office
description:
From the Rules:
The Box Office theatrical board game is based on producing plays for the stage.  As a player, you become a producer seeking to win by earning the most money by producing plays.

The Box Office theatrical board game has been developed by Canadian Cultural Consultants Corporation as a fund raising tool for Canadian and American theaters.

As producers, players move around the board, which represents various North American theaters, seeking to produce plays to which they own the rights.  If producers don't have the right compliment of actors in their stable, they may have to barter with other producers to borrow an actor with the right talents.

Another part of the game board are a few 'Make Or Break' spaces, which add in a number of random events, such as losing or gaining an actor, or added box office revenues.

Winner is the producer who first reaches a certain dollar number, which the players pre-determine.

Rules specify four players, don't know why it couldn't be played with fewer.

title: Global Neighbors
description:
A Mennonite Central Committee (MCC) Game

The heart of the game is answering trivia about the MCC and its activities.  Many of the answers are found in the information sheets included with the game.  The game was to be educational, fun to play and might even raise some dollars for MCC.

Global Neighbors is played on a board of the world.  At the start of the game, information sheets are divided amongst the players and each player is given responsibility for several different countries.  In order to win, you must be the first to visit each of the countries you are responsible for.  You move along the board by successfully answering trivia questions.

On your turn you must answer a question from one of the Question Cards.  Each Card has four different numbers on it.  If you answer the question correctly, you can move your marker a number of spaces equal to any one of the numbers on the card.  If you fail to answer a question, you cannot move and you must share some information from one of your Information Cards.

Components:
-    Mounted Game Board
-    Location Tiles (one for each country on the game board)
-    Player Markers (6)
-    Information Sheets (25)
-    Question Cards (270, double-sided)
-    Rules

title: The Wizard of Oz
description:
Quiz Game made in England in 1962 by Bell Toys.

It is a family quiz game called the The Wizard of Oz. This works along the same lines as the Magic Robot games that were also made in the 1960's.

There are sheets of questions and answers covering eight different categories. You stand the Wizard figure in the red magnetic base and move his pointer to a question. You then place him on the mirror in the middle of the answers section and he will magically move his pointer to answer your question.

He always gives the correct answer - he is a very clever little man!

Contents:

1 board
1 Wizard figurine
4 overlay mats with questions and answers

title: Dino Jump-a-Saurus
types: Abstract Strategy Children's Game Miniatures Prehistoric
description: Based on the award-winning Traverse game, this one features not wooden shapes but 4 different dinosaurs on 4 differently shaped bases. Same objective as Traverse - get your pieces to the other side (or trek across the prehistoric landscape). Tyrannosaurus = triangle with three-direction move. Velociraptor = diamond, moves diagonally. Triceritops = square, moves orthogonally. Stegosaurus = round, moves like chess queen. The board features lava pits and water slides. Easy version for ages six and up. Advanced version also, plus variants like Stampede, Water Slide, Hot Lava and Lava Luck. For extra excitement, try combining the rules for two or more variations.

title: Ys+
description: The 5 player expansion for Ys was released in Essen 2005. It also includes new character cards (12) and event cards (14), +5 gem cards (22), player aid cards (6), an additional screen, a marker and 14 blue broker cylinders for the fifth player, and additional rules.

title: Aber på Rov
mechanisms: Dice RollingMemoryPick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description:
The coconuts are ripe, and the monkeys fight over the coconuts. Each player controls two monkeys. Monkeys climb the tree to pick the coconuts, but also to steal coconuts from each other, push each other down, or just to another palm leave. First player to get 5 coconuts into his home wins the game.

Recommended Ages 7 and up

title: The Impossible Game
description:
Roll dice as few times as possible to match symbols shown on the game board. Symbols must be matched in rows of six. Rows must be across or up and down. Each row of symbols must be matched in not more than 3 rolls of the dice per turn.

A player who has filled a row of symbols picks up the six dice and places a strip of cardboard over that row of symbols and continues to play, attempting to match dice with symbols in any of the remaining rows.  The same player continues to play as long as he can complete an uncovered row of symbols.  As rows are filled (or covered) the game becomes more challenging.  Filling a row in the three rolls becomes more difficult.  If a player does succeed in covering all the rows without ever giving up the dice, he has achieved the IMPOSSIBLE.

title: Wargaming: an Introduction
types: American Civil War Ancient Medieval Miniatures Napoleonic Renaissance
description:
This book introduces the hobby of miniatures wargaming, presenting the history of miniatures wargaming, how to collect and paint miniatures, and--taking up most of the book--simple yet (reasonably) realistic rules and army lists for a wide range of historical periods, from ancients to WW2, including special skirmish-level rules.

Its Ancient rules were later expanded into another full book:


    Ancient & Medieval Wargaming


by the same author.

title: Alternative Games for the Family
description:
From the back of the book:
The alternative games in this booklet are all designed to be played with standard equipment. They offer exciting new dimensions to games played on or with draught boards, cards, pool tables etc., helping to eliminate the constant financial burden of purchasing expensive and often short-lived new games.

This is one of at least three booklets with rules for games designed and published by New Zealander, Tony Crow. Two other titles are Alternative Games for Those Who Like a Challenge and Alternative Games for the Studious.

The games are variations on existing games like draughts, ludo and Scrabble. The booklet is divided into four sections: Card Games, Draught Games, Other Games and Billiard Table Games.

title: The Road to Peace
description:
The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA)produced 10,000 of this game for disadvantaged children throughout Afghanistan.

The game aims to teach children about the key events in the peace process and reconstruction of Afghanistan. It also highlights key issues such as the environment, health, and education.

Players spin a spinner and move their piece (not included) along a path from the past to the future. Along the way they land on squares indicating positive or negative events that either send the player forward or backward.

title: Solo Ball
description:
This baseball game aims to re-create the game of baseball without specifically duplicating the efforts of real-life Major League Baseball players.  The owner of the game simply specifies a number of 'teams' for a league, and then plays out a number of contests to determine a winner.  The 'teams' are simply a bunch of names, since players have no specific individual characteristics.

The game engine is a set of 100 cards with a series of play results on them.  Results are situation specific; thus a play with one out will turn out differently depending on whether there are runners on 1st base, 2nd, 3rd, or none on.  Each card also has two orientations, with a different set of play results on each side.

The game was marketed in conjunction with The Sporting News magazine.  Included was an abbreviated version of TSN's booklet, Batting And Pitching Averages At A Glance, which is designed to help the player figure out batting averages and other stats for his 'teams'.

title: Instant Math Games that Teach
description: This book contains 38 games recommended for grades two through five, but older kids or adults could enjoy them, too. Templates for dice or spinners are included, but usually all that is needed is a few markers or coins. Variants on Nim, Magic Squares and Tic-Tac-Toe, as well as games using tangrams, pentominoes and other manipulatives. Aimed at teachers, but has nicely presented abstract strategy games as well as those involving numbers.

title: Classic Dice Games
description:
A multitude of popular dice games:

Flip-Up - Roll 2 dice and mark off the number you rolled or any two that add up to what you rolled. Try to get all 12 numbers (1 through 12) marked off

Yacht - basically Yahtzee, just a different name as Yahtzee is copyrighted.

Bunco -  A three-of-a-kind of the number that corresponds to the round (three 1's in Round One, three 2's in Round Two and so on.)

Ship, Captain, and Crew - Get the highest score on the total of three rolls, but you must get a 6 (ship), a 5 (captain), and a 4 (crew) in that order before any score can count

Hog - Roll 2 dice and get that many points, winner is the first to 100. However, if you get a single 1, you score nothing. If you get 2 1's, your total score goes back to 0

Hi-Dice - Score the highest amount of points based on 5 rolls, but at least one die must be set aside each roll
Poker Dice - Get the best possible poker but there are no suits and straights do not count.

Game includes large print score pads for Yacht and Bunco, 5 oversized 6-sided dice, felt-lined dice cup, flip up board, felt pad and instructions

title: Gladstone's Games to Go
types: Abstract Strategy Book Deduction Memory Party Game Puzzle
description:
Gladstone's Games to Go describes over 45 games, none requiring any special equipment beyond paper, pencils, and coins.  The book is divided into the following sections:

I. VERBAL GAMES (no equipment needed)

II. COIN GAMES

III. PEN-AND-PAPER GAMES
  A. General (Tic-Tac-Toe variants and Nim)
  B. Dots and Doodles
  C. Hidden Secrets
  D. Word Games

Most of the games can be played by two players; some can be played with a large group, and others can even be played solitaire. Some of the games, like Ghost and Nim, are well-known: others, like Moka and Tri-Dots, may be less familiar.

title: Advanced Tactics
description:
This game has been described as glorified War, but that description is almost entirely misleading.  Advanced Tactics uses one standard deck of cards for each player. The players battle over pairs of cards face up on the table, and draw three cards that are used to augment the strength of one or more of the pairs of cards in play. Clubs count as negative points, and diamonds require another card to be drawn for that column. The object of the game is not to simply win more cards, but to win point cards. Point cards start with the Aces, then move to Kings when all of the Aces are claimed, and so on. Play is continued until all points are claimed through a pre-agreed goal (for example, if playing to Queens, then the game will end when all Aces, Kings, and Queens are claimed). The player with the most point cards wins. This makes for interesting longer-term strategy as well as the obvious short-term strategy of winning the current cards on the table.

Complete rules for this game are in the July 2007 issue of Knucklebones magazine. Several rules variants are also included.

title: Walker's Tour Through France
description: Full title: Walker's Tour through France Being a New Geographical Game Containing Many Interesting Particulars of the Present State of the Principle Cities, Towns, Villages, Mountains, Rivers, c., in that Kingdom.. Early 19th century board game comes in slip case box which measures approx. 5 1/2 x 7 and contains an 84 page booklet titled A Key to Walker's Geographical Tour Through France with Directions for Making the Tour and a folding, hand colored Game Board being a map of France with a trail of 199 game spots tracing a tour through the entire country beginning at spot #1 (Calais) and ending at spot #199 (Paris). The map is linen backed and folds out to approx. 21 1/2 x 20 1/2. The map is marked London. Published June 6th, 1815 by Wm Darton Junr. 58 Holborn Hill ___ Of Whom may be had Walker's Instructive Geographical Tours of the World, Europe, England  Wales, Scotland  Ireland.. Among the very earliest commercially manufactured Board Games produced.

title: Line of Battle (first edition)
description:
LINE OF BATTLE: Tactical Capital Ship Combat, 1912 through 1924. A Tactical Study

Lord Fisher started it all when, in December of 1905, he approved the laying of the keel of Dreadnought, the first of a type of line of battle ship that would make everything built before it obsolete and whose concept would dominate the big gun ships of major navies for the next 40 years. By the eve of the Great War full fleets of these vessels faced each other across the narrow European seas, ready to fight for domination of the open ocean.

In an integrated combat system the game covers shell strengths, immune zones, armor placement, gun ranges, and angle of incoming shot without resort to complicated calculations. Detailed rules on movement, command, and other vital factors complete the game. 400 unit counters are included to cover every European, American,  Japanese dreadnought of the period.

Scenarios include Dogger Bank, Jutland, and hypothetical battles.

Re-implemented by:

    Line of Battle (second edition)

title: Flip Your Lid
description: Players must propel a (very small) hat up a thin pole to flip the rim of a much larger hat which effectively forms the roof of a gazebo-like structure, with the four thin poles serving as corner posts.  A spinner at the center of the structure dictates action and scores are kept using the sliding indicators located adjacent to each player.

title: Spade Town Challenge
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:
SPADE TOWN CHALLENGE is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the town of LURGAN in Northern Ireland. It is situated on the south shores of the Lough Neargh, 20 miles south-west of Belfast.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The New Share Quotations square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.

title: Viele Tiere
description:
This is a collection of three games of increasing complexity for small children.  All games involve a set of 34 cards that depict animals.  Large animals may require up to 4 cards (the pictures are too big to fit on a single card) and small animals take only 1.  The cards start the game mixed-up and face-down.

Small and Big Animals:

Each player in turn flips a card.  If you notice a complete animal on your turn then you collect all of the cards that make up the animal.  (If someone doesn't notice an animal then you can pick it up on your turn in addition to flipping a card and possibly picking up another animal.)  The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

Quick Zookeepers:

As above, but the animal goes to the first player to touch a zoo keeper card with the same background colour.

Chaos in the Zoo:

This is played like the card game Memory.  Flip cards until you get a complete animal or mismatched parts.  Take complete animals and turn mismatched ones face down for the next player.

title: Escrete
description: Escrete is a game where each player starts as a soccer team manager trying to buy players and organize the best squad. After that, each player becomes the coach, planning the better tactics to use during the match and, at last, the player turns into the hired soccer players, trying to do incredible moves that will drive the audience crazy. Wins the game the player who wins the tournament.

title: Final Combat
types: Modern Warfare Vietnam War Wargame World War II
description: Final Combat is a 20th century skirmish rules system for 15-54mm miniatures that emphasizes squad level engagements of WWII.  It strives for a realistic simulation of CQB and uses a spreadsheet for fast acquisition and combat resolution.

title: Lucky Luke Rodeo
types: Adventure American West Comic Book / Strip
description: a very rare boardgame..a rodeo tournament involving horse racing, shooting and knife using ability..a must for all the LUCKY LUKE comics fans

title: Floaties & Sinkies!
types: Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Miniatures Nautical Pirates Wargame
description:
This expansion for the first edition of the 25mm miniatures game, Pirates!  Miniature Battles on the High Seas, provides new ships, new ordnance, new races (dark dwarves, dark elves, reptilians, and halflings), and creature creation rules. Rules for dirigibles and submarines have also been included.

Pirates! 2nd  3rd editions contain all the FS! content within the main rulebook.

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module B – Terrain Maps
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
One of the first modules of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

Star Fleet Battles - Captain's Module B: Terrain Maps, came out before the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition Basic Set since it could also be used with the previous Star Fleet Battles Commander's Edition.

This module contains six scenarios and six terrain maps for Star Fleet Battles:

The terrain maps include:


     Ringed Gas Giant (Dimensions of Saturn)
     Blackfoot Pass (A famous historical asteroid field along the Federation/Klingon Border with a narrow pass through the field)
     Asteroid Field (1)
     Asteroid Belt (2)
     Black Hole (Showing the gravitational effects zones as described in SFB)
     Open Space (Standard 30x42 Hex Map)


The back cover of this module also includes a cutout of a:

     Thoilian Web (Three layer web, typically found around Tholian Bases)




Notes:
(1) republished as bonus with special back ground in Scenario Book #2
(2) republished as bonus with special back ground in Scenario Book #1

title: Star Fleet Battles: Module C4 – Fleet Training Centers
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

From the back of the cover

This product adds new rules, races and ships for Star Fleet Battles:

- The Frax: Based on wet navy warships with FX and RX firing arcs. Their subs use the gravitic Axion Torpedo.

- The Britanians: Their cruiser mounts no less than eight disruptors - four on each side! Cross the T to victory.

- The Sharkhunters: A cloaked ship's nightmare, they use flashbombs for lock-on and wire-guided plasmas for the kill!

- The Qaris: Their ships mount rapid-fire kinetic cannons in rotating turrets. Their gigantic Scud missiles kill bases.

- The Flivvers: Float like a butterfly - and kick like a mule! Speed-640 Huperdrones cannot be stopped easily.

- The Barbarians: Their ships have option mounts able to hold weapons and other systems to simulate any enemy.

- The Triaxians: Their ships move in three direcions (rather than two) and mount the versatile Type-A Plasma Torpedo.

- The Deltans: Designed for ONE mission - base busting! They are the fastest ships able to hold overloaded photons.

- The Canadi'ens: Their Maple Leaf Maulers will hit you coming and going, right and left, up and down, in and out.

title: Chess Mutation
description: This is a Chess variant in which all pieces other than kings move and attack according to the space that they are resting upon.  The board is marked with colours indicating each of the normal chess pieces (other than kings).  Due to the board colouring, pieces initially act like the pieces that usually occupy their starting positions.

title: Festival Internacional de Cinema Fantàstic de Sitges, The Game
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game Trivia
description:
Festival Internacional de Cinema Fantstic de Sitges - The Game is a game that represents the life during the Film Festival, with questions and answers about the Fantastic Film Festival and about the town of Sitges.

The Players, with a maximum number of 6, or in groups, have to move around Sitges, eat, sleep and go to the film sessions, with the object of seeing the most number of films.

The incidents of the game will take place on different squares and there will be questions to answer depending on the day an on the throw of the 3 die.

Components:
The Book of instructions and questions
A board representing the town of Sitges in the Festival area
6 Tokens one of each colour
12 food markers (two for each player)
24 sleep markers (four for each player)
6 passes to mark the answers (one for each player)
An assembled box to place the tokens and passes once they have been used
A Timing/List and squares included in the book.

title: Taunton Deane Dilemma
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:
TAUNTON DEANE DILEMMA is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the town of Taunton, Somerset in the West of England near the border with Wales. The YMCA's founder George Williams was born in Somerset and founded the Taunton branch in 1855.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The New Share Quotations square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.

title: The Glasgow Game
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:

The YMCA there is famous for its large hostel, housing some 400 young men.

This game is distinctly different from the other Ricken/Triaktiv games being predominantly Black in colour where the norm is a green or plum colour. See the pictures for greater detail of this.

Gloucester is one of Britains famous Roman ports and is also near the Cotswolds and the Forest of Dean.

title: Was is es?
description:
Main part of this game are 507 cards with rebus-puzzles. In their turn, players roll a die to get near the goal. If there are spezial signs on the landing field, they get a riddle-card and an hourglass-time to solve it. Success leads to advancement on the plan. First player in goal solving a master-puzzle wins.

The puzzles are all in German and therefore not language-independent.

title: GEOMAG Magnetic Challenge
description: A board game incorporating the fascinating attraction of GEOMAG magnetic world with a new game of strategy and skill. This board game has a metal core which allows the pieces to 'stick' to the board. Great for use in the home and even on the move in the car. GEOMAG Magnetic Challenge uses standard GEOMAG components and the special board to create the most captivating board game. The game consists of a snake of GEOMAG which moves from one side of the board to the other. The opponent must block the snake from occupying their start position whilst trying to reach the other end of the board themselves

title: Taverne de la Licorne
description:
This is a game designe to simulate a tavern brawl.
Each player receives 3 characters with different powers, a little money, 30 hit points and the 9 weapon cards.
Before the first turn, each player chooses one of his characters, that will be played until the character has lost all hit points. Then he'll use any one of the two remaining until they suffer the same fate, upon which he'll use his last character.
The turn is divised in 4 segments. All player undertake a segment before any begins the following segment.

The 4 segments are:
- Dpensez vos butins (expense your loot) where you can buy some of the big weapons cards and add them to your hand (the small ones are ALWAYS in your hand)
- Prparez vos esquives (prepare your dodges) where you put on your character, face up, any of the weapons you bought, up to the prestige (fame) value of your character
- Attaquez (attack) where each player chooses a weapon in hand and say who he attacks (players at his side for contact weapons, other players with ranged weapons)
- Videz vos querelles (end your quarrels) where attacks are resolved. An attack is dodged if the defensive player has correctly found the value of the attack coming. A succesful attack make the defensive character lose some of his HP, and the attacking character win prestige or loot.

In plus of the weapons card, there are other cards that players can use to affect the game.

If a player arrives at 5 in prestige, he can call the militia that will end the game. If a character becomes KO by losing all his Hit Points, its player takes his next character.

A player can come in the game, or leave, at any moment. The game is conceived for that.

La Taverne de la Licorne (tavern of the unicorn) is a light hearted tavern, in opposition of La Taverne de la Crypte, which is a tavern with undeads and horrors.
Both games are decorated with cartoon art.

title: Taverne de la Crypte
description:
This is a game designed to simulate a tavern brawl.
Each player receives 3 characters with different powers, a little money, 30 hit points and the 9 weapon cards.
Before the first turn, each player chooses one of his characters that will be played until that character has lost all hit points. Then he'll use any one of the two remaining until they suffer the same fate, upon which he'll use his last character.

The turn is divided in 4 segments. All players undertake a segment before any begins the following segment.

The 4 segments are:
- Dpensez vos butins (expense your loot) where you can buy some of the big weapons cards and add them to your hand (the small ones are ALWAYS in your hand)
- Prparez vos esquives (prepare your dodges) where you put on your character, face up, any of the weapons you bought, up to the prestige (fame) value of your character
- Attaquez (attack) where each player chooses a weapon in hand and say who he attacks (players at his side for contact weapons, other players with ranged weapons)
- Videz vos querelles (end your quarrels) where attacks are resolved. An attack is dodged if the defensive player has correctly found the value of the attack coming. A successful attack make the defensive character lose some of his HP, and the attacking character win prestige or loot.

In plus of the weapons card, there are other cards that players can use to affect the game.

If a player arrives at 5 in prestige, he can call the militia that will end the game. If a character becomes KO by losing all his Hit Points, its player takes his next character.

A player can come in the game, or leave, at any moment. The game is prepared for that occurence.

La Taverne de la Licorne (tavern of the unicorn) is a light hearted tavern, in opposition of La Taverne de la Crypte, which is a tavern with undead and horrors.
Both games are decorated with cartoon art and can be combined.

title: La Taverne du Dragon
description:
Third installation of the series La Taverne de after Taverne de la Licorne and Taverne de la Crypte, this game can be combined with the other two, and is in the same style of cartoon medieval fantasy humor.

This is a game designed to simulate a tavern brawl.
Each player receives 3 characters with different powers, a little money, 30 hit points and the 9 weapon cards.
Before the first turn, each player chooses one of his characters, that will be played until the character has lost all hit points. Then, he'll take any of the lasting twos until the same arrives, upon which he'll take his last character.

The turn is divided in 4 segments. All player undertake a segment before any begins the following segment.

The 4 segments are:
- Dpensez vos butins (expense your loot) where you can buy some of the big weapons cards and add them to your hand (the small ones are ALWAYS in your hand)
- Prparez vos esquives (prepare your dodges) where you put on your character, face up, any of the weapons you bought, up to the prestige (fame) value of your character
- Attaquez (attack) where each player chooses a weapon in hand and say who he attacks (players at his side for contact weapons, other players with ranged weapons)
- Videz vos querelles (end your quarrels) where attacks are resolved. An attack is dodged if the defensive player has correctly found the value of the attack coming. A successful attack make the defensive character lose some of his HP, and the attacking character win prestige or loot.

In plus of the weapons card, there are other cards that players can use to affect the game.

If a player arrives at 5 in prestige, he can call the militia that will end the game. If a character becomes KO by losing all his Hit Points, its player takes his next character.

A player can come in the game, or leave, at any moment. The game is conceived for that.

title: Hitler's Last Gamble
description:
Rand Games Associates' entry for Battle of the Bulge, unique for the use of German identification symbols on the German counters. This title was one of the two release in their second year of subscription games (along with Brandy Station) before they went out of business. Collectively titled Command Series, Vol 1. included nine games in a single red storage box, and Command Series, Vol 2. was projected to have 6 titles).

The game is the traditional hex based CRT combat system wargame with a smallish map of the Ardennes. The scale is regimental/brigade level with 2 turns per day of battle.

title: Stick Puzzle Poker
description: Stick Puzzles were a short-lived experiment similar to jigsaw puzzles but composed of two-sided, rectangular cardboard sticks rather than the traditional interlocking pieces.  Most of these were simply pictures to assemble, but one was also a game.  Stick Puzzle Poker, in addition to being a puzzle where each side shows a different set of ten poker hands, also includes rules for traditional poker and multiple variants including several that make use of the puzzle as part of the game.  Although the actual use of the puzzle in the game is minimal (simply defining which parts of the deck should be pulled and used as community cards), the set does allow for a variety of different ways to play: Hole in the Head, Low Blow, High-Low Split Stikeroo, Twin Sticks, Flip Stick Rollover, Stickeroo, Stackpoli High-Low, Super High-Low, Bean-Go Draw, Stick-O-Dynamite and Acupuncture Stud.

title: Shopping Spree
description:
You have a pocket full of money, so you're off on a shopping spree. Each time you stop at a store, you'll make a purchase. If you spend all your money, or worse yet, lose some, you'll have to earn more! Roll a die and move your shopping basket in either direction on the circular path to reach the shops and buy goods.

Introduces young children to the concepts of earning spending and planning ahead. Who will complete their shopping first? Be sure to use your money wisely! Three levels of play are included so this game can grow in complexity as your children grow. For 2 to 4 players. Ages 4 and up.

title: Junior Othello
description:
Published by Peter Pan Playthings under license from Anjar Co. USA, Junior Othello is Othello played on a 6x6 board (rather than an 8x8 board).

This shorter version of Othello has been solved - it is a win for the second player.

title: Galaksens Herskere
description:
Tongue in cheek science fiction game, where 2-5 players battle for rulership of the galaxy.
Each player start out with control of one planet, and then proceed to conquer planets either from the other players or from neutral territories.
You spend your income to buy factories, anti-missile systems and other planetary defenses, or you could spend it all on troops! A chit drawing system is used for troop acquisition, and the troops vary in types from rabbits to space pigs and other silliness.

title: The Maiden City Game
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:
THE MAIDEN CITY GAME is a Monopoly style board game developed by the Londonderry, Norther Ireland YMCA to generate funds for its activities.

When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

title: Yeo Valley Challenge
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:
YEO VALLEY CHALLENGE is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the town of Clevedon in the West of England.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

title: Turquoise
description:
The players place square tiles on which footbridges and pillar places are printed. Footbridges are pathways used by players to transport pillars.
Then they place new square tiles on the pillars, new pillars on the plates and so on in order to build a pyramid.

Each player scores points when he places tiles. The number of points depends on the pillars on which the tile is placed. The more the pyramid rises, the more these tiles make points. Thus each player must try to place a maximum number of tiles and to place them on pillars of his own color.

When the pyramid is finished, some penalties are given to the players who let unused pillars on the building site. The foreman who has got the most points gets glory, wealth, women and horses.

title: Swoop
description:
From the box: Swoop - A Game of Star-To-Star Strategy.  Ages 8 and up, for 2 to 4 players.  Instructions en Francais a l'interieur.

This is an abstract game with a light theme.  Each player has six spacemen (colored tokens) that start the game around the edge of the circular board on spots of cooresponding colors.  Players take turns moving their spacemen one at a time, a token can move one space left, right, inward but not diagonal nor outward, trying to get them into their home that is in the middle of the board and facing the opposite side as the starting position.  Checking is when a spaceman lands on an opponent's spaceman freezing it in place, and when it moves off, the checked or frozen spaceman is sent back to its starting location.

There are also star spaces that are check-free for the spaceman that occupies it.  That spaceman cannot be frozen or sent back to the starting locations.

title: Fetch!
description:
